characters: WE OPEN OUR EYES TO SEE --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RACHEL BIEGLER, early forties, lies half-naked on her sid surrounded by sheets and pillows. Her head rests on an ar as she stares into space, thinking. Rachel’s underpants a the kind you'd find in a twelve-pack: moss green cotton bikinis with lots of little flowers. The elastic waistban is separating in one spot.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Are you ready? (0.8.)

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Yeah. Rachel fluffs up a pillow and plants her face in it. (muffled) I’m ready.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Alrightie... (0.8.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a sun rising over forties, in boxers and curve of Rachel's hip. and after a considered a mountain, RICHARD GRIMES, mid- a faded T-shirt, appears above the He sits up on his knees behind her pause, pulls Rachel’s underwear down.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Just breathe, okay? (a beat) Are you breathing?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (muffled and annoyed) Yes! Gol

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Okay. Richard lays one hand on her haunch and with the other ra a SYRINGE with a LARGE NEEDLE. He nervously takes aim -- One... two... three. -- and spears the needle into his wife’s flesh.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Owww! Fuck! Richard!

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD RACHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What?! That fucking hurts!

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I’m sorry. Richard’s hand trembles as he pulls the plunger back to for blood. There is none, so he pushes the plunger down.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Almost done. Almost done. Almost done. Done. Richard pulls out the needle; Rachel looks at her hip.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I think you hit a nerve. Still holding the syringe, Richard uses his teeth to open a SMALL FOIL ENVELOPE, causing him to slur --

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Uhm shorry, honey. I did ekshactly what the nursh told me to do. He spits out the torn-off strip, removes an ALCOHOL PAD a presses it over the injection site just as TWO RESCUE DOG ENO and LAZLO, click into the room and hop up on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (pointing) Wasn’t it supposed to be more like here?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Nope. Upper outer quadrant.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Then why did it hurt like that? Nobody on the message boards said it’s supposed to hurt like that.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I don’t know, Rache. It’s a bigger needle. Maybe you have a lower pain threshold than most people. I don’t know. I’m not a doctor. Remember? Rachel watches Richard as he climbs off the bed and drops used syringe in a PLASTIC WATER BOTTLE that already conta dozen others. This new, larger one, lands with a dull CLU

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Are you mad at me?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: No. I’m not mad. I’m just... Whatever. I don’t know. Tired. Richard picks up something from a nearby bureau and offer it to Rachel: It’s A BAG OF FROZEN PEAS. Husband and wife regard each other for an odd moment, th Rachel takes the peas, places them on her aching ass and Richard leaves. CUT TO BLACK. UNDER BLACK, A CARD -——

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big, bright modern space with large windows. At 7:15 A. it’s already packed with (mostly white) women in their la and early 40s. Some are accompanied by husbands. Some are alone. There are several Hasidic couples. One lesbian cou Among this crowd are Rachel and Richard. SUPERIMPOSE -—

dialogues.speaker: THE RETRIEVAL
dialogues.text: Richard does the crossword puzzle while Rachel sits with unread magazine on her lap, furtively observing her fello patients, including -- A TENSE WOMAN, dressed for work, tapping her Blackberry. Rachel’s eyes float down to the woman’s HANDSOME LEATHER PUMPS with gold buckles, then Rachel examines her own shoes: OLD SAUCONYS in dingy yellow. DING! The elevator arrives and Rachel watches as a SINGLE WOMAN steps out, wheeling a CRYOGENIC TANK. The woman scans the room for an empty seat. There are none, so she just stands there, stranded with her tank of frozen sperm With the SWOOSH of a door, a NURSE emerges and everyone looks up expectantly.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Rachel? Rachel rises, holding her coat, scarf and purse in an awkward heap as the magazine drops to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WEDDING BAND, WATCH and NECKLACE are placed one at a ti on a Formica surface next to CELLOPHANE WRAPPED HOSPITAL GARMENTS . WIDER shows Rachel in her underwear and socks as she unsc an earring. We notice a CHAIN OF PURPLE INJECTION BRUISES above her panty line as she looks around the sterile room wondering how she ended up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel stuffs her parka, purse and clothes into a tiny lo

dialogues.speaker: ADMITTING NURSE, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: These are your consent forms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard stands at a desk as an ADMITTING NURSE presents him with various documents.

dialogues.speaker: ADMITTING NURSE
dialogues.text: Both partners signatures are required on the second page. This is our policy regarding embryo storage. The fee schedule is on the back. You both need to initial each paragraph then sign here. She fastens the documents onto a clipboard and hands it t him. As Richard turns to go -- And this is for you. She disappears behind the desk and reappears with a PLAST BAG containing A SPECIMEN CUP. Instructions are inside. Richard takes the cup and smiles awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: There you are! Richard turns to see Rachel approaching in a HOSPITAL GOW PAPER SHOWER CAP and her locker key dangling from her wri She seems anxious.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Nothing. It’s fucking freezing in here. Richard puts an arm around her and rubs her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Shhh. Relax. Don’t obsess.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I’m not obsessing. I’m cold. He guides her into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and they sit down among several other couples.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (handing her the clipboard) You need to sign these. As Rachel begins examining the papers, she mumbles to her

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh, my god. What are we doing? Are we really doing this? Are we insane?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: We’re not insane. We’re normal. Richard folds back the papers and points out a signature

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (signing) This is not normal. This is the opposite of normal. I’m not sure if it’s even ethical. Remember what Marty said? “Having a baby is an immoral act.”

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Marty’s an idiot.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: “Overpopulation, climate change... Richard notices a nearby couple giving them looks. ...the rise of neo-fascism --”

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Did you take your Valium?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Yes. Why?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Ms. Biegler? Rachel turns to see a nurse standing a few feet away. Rac signals that she’ll be right there, then turns back to Ri

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Okay, I guess we’re doing this.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Don’t be scared, okay? You're gonna do great. All we need is one good egg, right?  Moved by her husband's optimism, Rachel smiles and nods.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You, too honey. Don’t be scared. You’re gonna do great. Richard smiles feebly and raises his specimen cup. Rachel chortles quietly. I love you.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I love you, too. They kiss. As Richard watches his wife being led off to surgery, we hear the incongruent SOUND of GRUNTING and MOANING.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: A NAKED WOMAN ON ALL FOURS with giant fake breasts being drilled from behind by a STEROID-ENHANCED MAN. He grunts; she moans. Wider reveals that we are watching the action on a wall-mounted VIDEO MONITOR in -- INT. “COLLECTION” ROOM - DAY Richard sits with his pants around his ankles and the emp SPECIMEN CUP in his hand, staring at the screen with a lo of profound despair. Unable to bear another moment, he aims the remote and pre STOP, but the horror show continues. Richard tries anothe button, but the moaning and grunting just get LOUDER. Desperate, he shakes the remote and TWO BATTERIES fall ou rolling across the floor. With his pants still around his ankles, Richard stands an shuffles to the monitor. A LARGE SHEET OF SANITARY PAPER stuck to his ass and CRINKLES loudly. CLICK, he switches off the MONITOR. Silence at last. Then

dialogues.speaker: ANESTHESIOLOGIST, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: My eight year old came to work one day...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ANESTHESIOLOGIST hovers over the camera.

dialogues.speaker: ANESTHESIOLOGIST
dialogues.text: ..--to see what I do. You know, “Take Your Daughter to Work Day.” REVERSE, Rachel is looking up from a surgical table as th anesthesiologist rambles on, injecting her with a sedati She said it was the most boring job in the world. All I do all day is put people to sleep. Rachel smiles politely as her eyes drift shut and we -- FADE TO BLACK. UNDER BLACK, HUSHED VOICES speaking in a foreign tongue. Hebrew?

dialogues.speaker: WE OPEN OUR EYES TO SEE --
dialogues.text: A BLURRY HASIDIC MAN in a dark suit standing next to his wife’s bed, talking to her. He wears a hat; she wears a w

dialogues.speaker: BLEARY-EYED RACHEL --
dialogues.text: observing her exotic neighbors as she wakes up. Rachel gets up on her elbows and looks around to find tha all the women in the surrounding beds have been joined by their husbands or partners. She calls to a passing NURSE.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (groggy, weak) Excuse me...(louder) Ma’am? Nurse? The nurse finally hears Rachel and goes to her. Where’s my husband?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Your birth partner hasn’t joined you? Rachel shakes her head. The nurse refers to her paperwork

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: He’s my husband.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL NURSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My birth partner... he’s... (mispronouncing as my husband. “Grimes” ) Not that that matters, it’s Mr. Grimes? just...

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (correcting “Grimes” ) Grimes. Yes. Richard Grimes. Rachel notices a flicker of concern on the nurse’s face she reads something on the clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: You’1ll need to speak to a Doctor. (walking away) Let me go find someone.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Is something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: It’‘ll be just a moment.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (mounting panic) Why can’t you just tell me? Hello! The nurse disappears. Fuck! Rachel’s eyes land on her Hasidic neighbors who regard he with flat stares. She smiles, but their faces remain expressionless.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE DOCTOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: There wasn’t any sperm. Rachel turns to discover a FEMALE DOCTOR at the foot of her bed. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Excuse me...

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Your husband didn’t have any sperm.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Wait. You mean, like... he couldn’t... do it?

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE DOCTOR
dialogues.text: No. He produced. And there was semen, but no sperm. (off Rachel's bewilderment) Dr. Dordick will have to give you the details. The doctor leaves and Rachel discovers Richard across the room looking at her with a defeated smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. DORDICK (60s), silver-haired and handsome in his scru stands at Rachel’s bed side and speaks to our beleaguered couple while drawing a diagram of the male reproductive system on a file folder.

dialogues.speaker: DORDICK
dialogues.text: Think of it like a soda machine. Either one of you ever work in a movie theater? The seltzer comes from one place. (pointing with his pen) The syrup comes from someplace else. Together they make Mountain Dew or Diet Coke or what have you. But if the pipe gets... clogged... (draws an X) .+-you don’t get Mountain Dew. You just get... seltzer. Richard is probably blocked.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Mentally? Like psychosomatic?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: No. Not mentally. Physically. Like what he’s just been talking about with the soda machine.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Right. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: DORDICK
dialogues.text: I just got off the phone with a buddy of mine. A urologist. Joel Fisher. He’s an expert on this. He’s writing a book about it. Dordick pulls out a XEROXED ARTICLE from New York Magazin and hands it to Richard. The title is: Male Menopause

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Oh, my god. That’s so depressing.

dialogues.speaker: DORDICK
dialogues.text: Don’t be depressed, Rich. Based on everything that I told him, he’s confident that you’ve got sperm in there. The trick is getting it out. Now, there’s a procedure for it. And Fisher is definitely the man for the job. It’s called... (pronounced “tessy”) TESE. Testicular sperm extraction.  10 Dordick hands Richard an information sheet on the procedu

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Oh, my god.

dialogues.speaker: DORDICK
dialogues.text: It’s not as bad as it sounds.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You know he only has one testicle, right? Richard looks at Rachel, incredulous. What? He needs to know.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I realize that. (sighs, then to Dordick.) I only have one testicle.

dialogues.speaker: DORDICK
dialogues.text: I saw the note in your file and I filled Fisher in. He doesn’t anticipate a problem. (pointing with his pen) What he’1l do is avoid the vas deferens and go right to the source by doing a testicular biopsy.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Like for cancer?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: No, Rachel. Not cancer. I don’t have cancer. I have blocked sperm!

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Sorry. He said biopsy.

dialogues.speaker: DORDICK
dialogues.text: The thing is if we do TESSE, we’ll have to follow up, with ICSE (pronounced “Icksy”) Intra-Cytoplasmic Sperm Injection. (handing Richard another sheet) It’s an additional expense, but there’s no way around it. The good news is Fisher is available and happens to be in the city today. The bad news is... he‘1l need a check for ten thousand dollars. I know it’s short notice.  11

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Not a problem.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: It’s not? Richard shakes his head. Dordick prepares to leave.

dialogues.speaker: DORDICK
dialogues.text: Take a minute to talk things over and once you're ready, I'll give Fisher a call while Moira helps Richard get suited up and we'll be off to the races.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard and Rachel walk down the hall following MOIRA. Rachel pushes her IV pole.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (hushed, but intense) Richard. We don’t have ten thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I’m gonna call Charlie. Rachel slows to a halt. Richard stops, too.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: We said we weren’t going to tell anybody.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I know... But what’re we supposed to do, Rache? Eleven of your eggs are sitting in there waiting to be inseminated and we don’t have anything to inseminate them with. Rachel watches with envy as ANOTHER COUPLE, finished with their procedure, walk arm-in-arm toward the exit. If I don’t call him we're screwed. The cycle will be a bust, we’ll have blown through a big chunk our baby budget and you’ll have gone through all this for nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard, now wearing a parka over a HOSPITAL GOWN, paces back and forth on the sidewalk, talking on his cellphone.  12 Rachel stands in the vestibule watching him through the glass door. After a few moments, Richard hangs up and heads inside, looking upbeat.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: He’s on his way with a check.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: He is?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Yep. They walk to the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Did Cynthia say anything?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What? No. Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: She's so judgmental.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: No, she’s not. The elevator arrives. Rachel’s Hasidic neighbors exit, an our couple steps in.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Yes, she is, Richard. She was even weird when we were doing IUIs.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You're being paranoid. The doors close. INT. CHARLIE’S BEDROOM/BATHROOM - DAY CYNTHIA (50s) with messy morning hair stares at someone o screen with her jaw dropped wide open.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: They're doing it again?! Reverse shows CHARLIE (50s) at the sink as he turns off t faucet and drags a towel over his wet face.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No. This is something totally different. New doctor. Very high tech with... egg harvesting... and hatching. And something called “Icksee.” Have you seen my pants?  13 Charlie slips past Cynthia, enters the adjoining bedroom starts sifting through strewn clothes.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: I thought they were done with all that and they were trying to adopt.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. They are. They’re still doing that. But after that thing with that girl, they’re trying a “by any means necessary” approach. Doing both at once.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Oh, my god. They’re like compulsive gamblers! Charlie finds his pants, steps into them.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Anyway, it’s really technical and hard to keep track of. But there’s a problem with Richard’s sperm and he needs to borrow ten thousand dollars. Charlie zips his pants and exits. Cynthia runs after him into -- THE HALLWAY --—

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: You're not going to give it to him?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Of course I am. He’1ll pay me back. Charlie arrives at the STAIRS and heads down. Cynthia follows.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Charlie, if you love Richard and Rachel, do not give them the money. They don’t need money. They need help. Giving them money is just... enabling them. Charlie shoots her a skeptical look as he enters -- THE LIVING ROOM. Cynthia is a few steps behind him.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: To what?  14

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: To pursue this... fantasy of fertility when it’s pretty clear that it’s consuming them -- emotionally and economically. They're strung out. Their marriage is a wreck. They’re always fighting. They’re like fertility junkies.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That’s nuts.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Honey. They’ve been doing this for years. They need to stop. They need to move on. They need an intervention. GIRL’S VOICE (0.S.) Mom? Cynthia and Charlie turn to see their daughter, CHARLOTTE holding A PHONE.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Sadie’s on the phone. She doesn’t sound good. Charlotte looks back and forth between her parents, neith of whom responds so she drops the phone on the couch and leaves. Cynthia and Charlie look at each other. Then, OUT OF THE RECEIVER, a faint voice --

dialogues.speaker: SADIE, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Mom?

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: (picking up) Hi, honey.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I need to get going. He pulls on a sweater. Cynthia follows him as he makes hi way to the front door where he grabs his coat and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SADIE BARRETT (25) stands outside a dormitory, shivering smoking as she talks on her cellphone. She’s wearing a th oversized sweater and pajama bottoms.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) I really want you to think about what you're doing.  15

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Mom? What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cynthia watches from the doorway as Charlie crunches acro the gravel driveway and -- VEEP! VEEP! -- unlocks their Mercedes Station Wagon.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Nothing. We’re just. Charlie’s going into the city and -- Before he gets in the car, Charlie calls out to Cynthia.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I'll pick up some stuff from Russ and Daughter’s. You want salmon?

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: (covering the phone) Charlotte! You want salmon?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: (louder) Dad’s going into Manhattan. You want Russ and Daughters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sadie struggles to hear, but she can only make out MUFFLE SOUNDS. Several students trudge by with backpacks. INTERC

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Mom?

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: (to Charlie) A bialy. An everything bagel. And a quarter pound of Wild Nova. (to Sadie) Sorry, honey. Is everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Uhh... not really.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: What’s wrong? Sadie takes a deep drag on her cigarette. Are you smoking?  16

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: (mouth full of smoke) No. I quit. I told you. (exhales away from phone) I just have a cold. And I’m standing outside and it’s freezing. She drops her cigarette and steps on it.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Tivoli. School.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Right. Okay. I was just checking. You sound funny. A pause as Sadie summons her courage.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: I need to get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: For the Holidays?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: No. Before the holidays. And after. (tense pause) I need to leave here for a while.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: You just got back there!

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: I know. I don’t think it was such a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: What do you mean? It was a great idea. You'll finally graduate.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: I’m not doing well.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Are you failing?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: No. God, mom. Emotionally, not academically. You are so achievement oriented.  17

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Finishing college at 25 isn’t exactly an achievement, Sadie. It’s damage control. Sadie’s eyes well up. Cynthia grimaces, regretting her choice of words. I’m sorry. I shouldn’t have said that.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: It’s what you think.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: No, it’s not. I just... want you to find something that you love doing that gives you a sense of purpose and meaning to your life.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: I found it. Remember? Cynthia tries to think of what Sadie is referring to. Writing...

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Of course. Yes. And you're really good at it, honey. But if you want to be a writer-writer, a professional, you have to be very driven and disciplined. And if it’s giving you this much trouble in college, what's going to happen in the real world when you need to pay your rent at the same time? Sadie shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: I’m not failing, Mom. I did a lot of good work at the beginning of the semester that I’m really proud of. It’s just... I’m a little stuck right now and I’m not gonna to be ready to hand in my portfolio in Writing Workshop which counts for like eighty percent of our grade. But the good news is my professor really believes in me and she’s willing to give me an incomplete which is great because... Sadie trails off.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Sadie? What?  Pause. 18

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Nothing. I guess I’m waiting for you to tell me that in “real life” there’s no such thing as an incomplete.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Honey, why don’t you just come home, and we can talk about this in person.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: I can’t come home, mom.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: (hesitant) Because... I want to be in the city.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Oh, god, Sadie, how’re you going to do that?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: I'll work. I'll waitress. It’s not gonna cost you a penny. I promise. Uncle Richard and Aunt Rachel said I could stay at their place whenever I want.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Honey, Richard and Rachel have a lot on their plate. Trust me. They’re not in a position to take care of anyone but themselves right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard and Rachel, the last remaining patients, lie in adjacent beds. He clutches an ice pack to his crotch, she a heating pad against her lower abdomen. MELANCHOLY LOW-FI PIANO MUSIC FADES IN as the CAMERA SLOW PULLS AWAY from our reproductively challenged couple.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: (singing) Nobody wants a broken toy.... The song transports us to --  19

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GIRL (10), holding a DOC McSTUFFINS’ KARAOKE MICROPHONE sings a song from the show while her YOUNGER SISTER does strange interpretive dance. A REVERSE shows Richard and Rachel watching with polite ambivalence. They sit with other MIDDLE-AGED DINNER GUESTS who form a captive, but charmed, audience. The song ends. The guests applaud. The children beam. CAROLINE (45), the hostess (and mother of the girls), tri to move things along --

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: Okay, you guys. Say good night to everyone.

dialogues.speaker: GIRLS
dialogues.text: Good night! A chorus of “Good night!” from the table as a BABY-SITTER herds the kids off to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The remaining guests lounge with wine and dessert. We drift through the room, catching bits of conversation. We hear a party-goer, DAVID, talk about alternate side parking rules. In a corner, we find Richard talking to Caroline’s husband BRAD. Rachel is nearby.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: It’s just party people drinking themselves sick on the weekends. I can barely walk the dogs at night. I just don’t want to find myself at fifty sitting at a block association meeting trying to prevent a new bar from opening.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Honey, we're not going to turn fifty on East 6th Street.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I’m forty-seven!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caroline removes a bottle of wine from the fridge as Rach enters, carrying dishes. We hear voices from the other ro

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You guys seem great.  20

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: Me and Brad? We haven’t spoken in two days.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: For the last forty-eight hours we have not uttered a word to each other. Just then, Brad enters the kitchen with some dessert plat That's how we fight. Right, honey? No words. Brad looks at Rachel, shrugs in agreement, deposits dishe on the counter and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: POP
dialogues.text: When’s your book coming out?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: April.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: (opening the wine) That's exciting. I haven’t written jack-shit since Talia was born. The cork comes out and Caroline begins to pour. You have got to try this. I’m obsessed. I drank it all summer.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: No, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: Really? It’s Prosecco. You’re not a Prosecco person?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: No. I am. I love it. It’s just, I can’t... I’m cycling.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: Oh, my god. Soul Cycle? My sister does that and her ass is like two little coconuts. Do you love it?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh, no. Not that kind of cycling. (hesitant) It’s... IVF.  21

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: (covers her mouth) Oh, my god. I am so sorry. What an idiot. She hugs Rachel.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: It’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: No, it’s not. I’m such a dope. Wow. I didn’t know you guys were back to doing that. I thought you we're trying to adopt.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: No. Yeah. We are. We just figured, while we're waiting, we might as well give this a shot. Ha! That’s a good one, right? Giving IVF a shot. It’s our first time, actually. We did lots of IUIs before, but we never brought out the big guns.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: It’ll really increase your chances, though, right?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Yeah. I don’t know. Our numbers aren’t so great.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: You should talk to my cousin, Erin. She did IVF to get her kids and her doctors told her she shouldn’t even bother. Her chances were like one percent or something. And she got pregnant twice. In her forties. With only one ovary. Rachel, rapt, mouths “wow.” I’m sure she’d love to talk to you about it. And her kids are amazing. Caroline pulls a photo of Erin and her two kids off the fridge and hands it to Rachel.

dialogues.speaker: A MONITOR
dialogues.text: displaying an enlarged microscopic image of what appears to be TWO CIRCLES OF SUDSY SPITTLE.  22 SUPERIMPOSE -—

dialogues.speaker: THE TRANSFER
dialogues.text: A WIDER ANGLE reveals that we are in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel, her feet in stirrups, lies on a table, tipped so her head is lower than her pelvis. LAB TECHNICIANS and NURSES stand at various stations around the room. Dordick in surgical scrubs, points to one of the spittle circles.

dialogues.speaker: DORDICK
dialogues.text: That’s a double-A embryo, right there. See the tightly packed cells.... That puppy is raring to go. We’ll transfer both, but I’m putting my money on this guy. (turning to Rachel) You ready?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (not sure) Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: DORDICK
dialogues.text: (a smile, then to the room--) Alrightie. Here we go, guys. It’s show time. LIGHTS dim. A GIANT SURGICAL LAMP GOES ON. Dordick sits on a stool with wheels and rolls in between Rachel’s legs Your job is to just relax and breathe, okay? Rachel nods, not relaxed at all. Dordick holds out his hand and a nurse supplies him with a SPECULUM.

dialogues.speaker: DORDICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This might feel a little cold... Just relax... That’s it. MELLOW GUITAR MUSIC begins to play. Do you like The Eagles? Rachel has no idea what he’s talking about until the vocals begin:

dialogues.speaker: EAGLES
dialogues.text: Every night... I'm lyin' in bed... Holdin' you close in my dreams... Dordick smiles and raises his eyebrows. Rachel politely smiles back and nods.  23 Dordick holds out a hand and an embryologist gives him a CATHETER. With one eye on Rachel’s cervix and the other o the ultrasound monitor, he speaks softly --

dialogues.speaker: DR. DORDICK
dialogues.text: Alright. Let’s get pregnant, shall we? Rachel smiles weakly and watches Dordick mouth the lyrics as he guides the catheter deep into her body.

dialogues.speaker: EAGLES
dialogues.text: Oh, oh, oh, oh, sweet darlin’ you get the best of my love...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel holds the collar of her coat closed as she and Ric stand on blustery First Avenue, searching for a cab. Spotting one, Richard raises his arm and a PIECE OF PAPER he’s holding is snatched from his hand by the wind.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh, my god! Richard. Richard chases the paper down the sidewalk, awkwardly crouching as he goes. Pedestrians step out of the way and give him looks. Rachel watches with a hand over her mouth

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard smooths the paper against his thigh and rubs it, trying to remove the dirt and creases. For the first time see that it’s a BLACK & WHITE IMAGE of their embryos. The cab hits a large pot hole, making a jarring dip and b

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Ugh. (to the driver) Excuse me? Sir? The PAKISTANI CAB DRIVER conversing in Urdu on his headse doesn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (quietly to Rachel) It’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: No, it’s not. I’m trying to implant. Rachel unbuckles her seat-belt and sticks her head throug the opening in the Plexiglass divider. Sir.  24 Startled, the driver yanks out his earbuds. Hi. I’m sorry, but I just had a medical procedure. Gynecological. The driver looks terrified. So if you would slow down and take it easy on the bumps, I’d appreciate it. As soon as Rachel retracts her head from the opening, the cabdriver slides the window shut. WHACK!

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: BATHROOM TILE being mercilessly scrubbed.

dialogues.speaker: THE HOME STUDY
dialogues.text: WIDER reveals we are in-- INT. RACHEL AND RICHARD’S APARTMENT - DAY Rachel is on all fours in the bathtub, scrubbing the tile Meanwhile, the dogs follow Richard as he enters the bedroom with an armful of fertility medication. He kicks the lid off a WICKER HAMPER and dumps everything inside.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (yelling) How are we doing?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Good! Richard spots the WATER BOTTLE filled with used syringes and tosses it into the hamper. As of now, no IVF materials are in sight. BACK IN THE BATHROOM -—

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Great!

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Do you think we should take down the Lisa Yuskavage?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: What? No! Richard has wandered into --  25 THE LIVING ROOM, where he stares at something off-screen.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I’m just looking at it from Beth's perspective. We’re used to it, but... If you and I sit next to each other on the couch and Beth sits across from us... Richard takes a seat in the only chair opposite the couch It’s like right in her face.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (entering with a sponge) What is?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: The vagina. ANOTHER ANGLE reveals a SEXUALLY EXPLICIT LITHOGRAPH of a nude woman with her legs splayed open. I think we should at least move it. So it’s not so... central.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (thinks for a moment, then --) No. Uh-uh. If our social worker is so uptight that she would actually deny us a child because we have a... vagina on our wall, well then... just... screw everything... Rachel marches back to the kitchen and gets down on all fours.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean, just fuck it! (shaking Ajax on the floor) I am so sick of these people judging us and telling us what to do all the time. Between the doctors and the social workers and the support groups, it’s just like, shut the fuck up already and shove it up your fucking asses!

dialogues.speaker: LATER, IN THE LIVING ROOM --
dialogues.text: A civilized tableau: Rachel and Richard, nicely dressed a flanked by their dogs, sit on the couch across from BETH (50), a compact social worker. While Rachel pours tea, Be reviews their file.  26

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: Before Kyra went on maternity leave she walked me through everything, so I'm pretty up-to-date. But nothing can replace talking face-to-face. (receiving her tea) Mmm, thank you. As Beth takes a sip, her eyes land on the lithograph and the VAGINA. She seems hypnotized by it. Richard gives Rachel an “I told you so” look.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: She's a good friend of ours. Not the woman in the picture. The artist who made it. She’s our friend. It was a wedding present.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: (back to business) So, it looks like you came to adoption after some fertility treatments. Nervous “Uh-huhs and “Yeahs” before an uncomfortable paus

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: It wasn’t for us. Didn’t feel right. Beth nods sympathetically as she writes something down.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Plus Richard only has one testicle, so... Richard shoots his wife a look. Beth moves things along.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: I see that you were matched with a birthmother last winter. Would you mind telling me a little bit about that? Richard and Rachel check in with each other. Richard nods

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Okay. Um. We’d been officially waiting for a couple of months and we weren’t getting any calls, which was totally depressing. Kyra told us about Parent Portraits... Beth nods knowingly. «+-SO we decided to give it a try. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 27 About a week after our page went up, we got a call... INT. RACHEL AND RICHARD’S APARTMENT - FLASHBACK - NIGHT A RINGING PHONE sits on a desk in their home office. Tape to it is a handmade label: BABY PHONE/INCOMING CALLS ONLY Rachel stumbles into the dark room, stubbing her toe en route -- “Oww, Fuck!”

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Hello. Yes. Uh-huh. That’s us. She turns on a lamp. With the handset wedged between her shoulder and ear, she pushes aside paperwork to reveal TW PAGES of what appears to be a play taped to the desk. A heading reads: PHONE SCRIPT. No, not at all. “We’re happy you called. It’s the perfect time.” Richard, in boxers, drifts into the room, squinting and scratching his head. Rachel looks at him, holds up a finger. Yep. New York City. Uh-huh. Well, it’s got its pros and cons. But we love it. Rachel scrawls on a notepad and shows it to Richard:

dialogues.speaker: TIFFANY 19
dialogues.text: Richard nods.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: What about you?... Uh-huh. Oh, wow. Birthplace of Bill Clinton! No. But we’ve always wanted to... She hastily writes something else for Richard: Little Rock, Ark -- 13 Weeks Pregnant Richard draws a deep breath and sighs as he watches his w sink deeper and deeper into the call.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It was like a match made in heaven.

dialogues.speaker: A SKYPE SESSION
dialogues.text: TIFFANY is on a computer screen, having an animated conversation with Rachel and Richard.  28 The voices are barely audible and the pixillated image is beautiful and strange, like a digital dream.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We talked to her almost every night for a month...

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER SKYPE SESSION --
dialogues.text: Tiffany gets up, adjusts her computer, then lifts her sweatshirt to reveal a BIG RED HEART drawn with lipstick her barely showing belly. Richard and Rachel smile in awe. Tiffany pops her head back into frame. Everybody laughs.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We fell in love with her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A key is inserted in a mailbox that says Biegler/Grimes. Among the mail is an ENVELOPE decorated with HEART STICKERS and a PURPLE UNICORN STAMP.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She was so young. It was like we were her parents. Richard opens the envelope and pulls out SEVERAL SONOGRAM along with a PHOTO of Tiffany which looks like it was taken at JC Penny's. INT. RACHEL AND RICHARD’S APARTMENT - DAY Richard puts the photo and sonograms on the refrigerator with a MAGNET IN THE SHAPE OF ARKANSAS.

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So you arranged to meet her? INT. RACHEL AND RICHARD’S APARTMENT - PRESENT

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Yep. Two days before Christmas. It was amazing we could get tickets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rental car whizzes by a sign that says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard drives. Rachel holds a beat-up manila folder in her lap and watches the landscape roll past. Richard spots something -- THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD -- A CRACKER BARREL.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Thar’ she blows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard turns into the parking lot, finds a spot and shut off the engine. They stare at the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: We're early. You want to go in or wait here?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Go in. (opening the door) I need to use the bathroom. Richard and Rachel walk toward the restaurant straighteni their clothing, which is dressier and more conservative than usual. Richard reaches for Rachel’s hand, then notices something and stops.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: On your neck. What is that? Rachel nervously fingers her necklace, and we see a TINY GOLD CROSS.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Jewelry.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I know that. Why are you wearing it?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (shrugging) I like it.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You're Jewish.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: No I’m not, my mother’s Irish Catholic.  30

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Your father’s Solomon Biegler.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Okay. So, I want Tiffany to like us.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: By lying to her?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I’m not lying. It’s just... a piece of jewelry. She can interpret it any way she wants.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Rache, we don’t have to pretend we’re something we’re not. She knows who we are. She thinks we’re cool. She’s not suddenly expecting Christians to show up. It’s not like we ever said anything in our Parent Profile about being religious, so we don’t need to start now. (off Rachel’s look) What?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I updated our page. Richard stares at his wife, baffled. It felt stale. It needed refreshing. So, I updated a few things.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You mean like our sudden belief that Jesus Christ is our savior?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Will you stop making me feel shitty about this? Jesus. Everyone in our group does it. They say they go to church on Sunday even if where they really go is just to... brunch or... pilates or whatever because they know that most of these girls with unwanted pregnancies aren’t really Sunday- brunch-pilates-people because if they were... they wouldn’t be in this... stupid situation in the first place because they would have already taken care of it by now by having had an abortion... (voice catching) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 31 «+.-Just like we did... nine years ago when we weren’t ready. Rachel’s breathing is shallow and jittery as she holds back tears.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: We weren’t ready, Rache. We were in graduate school. In enormous debt. We had just met. We didn’t even like each other yet. Rachel lets out a little snort-laugh. Richard laughs a little, too. They fall silent a moment.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Do you ever think that that’s why now we can’t --

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: No. I don’t. Ever. A moment. Then Richard holds out a hand. Rachel takes it, and they resume walking toward the restaurant. FROM BEHIND, as they walk away --

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: It’s just a piece of jewelry.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I think it’s pretty. It looks good with my blouse.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Yeah. It does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WAITRESS arrives at the booth and places MEATLOAF in front of Richard and ICED TEA in front of Rachel.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Mmm. That looks great. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: (to Rachel) Are you sure there’s nothing else I can get for you?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: No, thank you.  32 As the waitress leaves, Richard takes a bite of meatloaf. Rachel takes a sip of her tea, looks out the window and s

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Honey, relax, okay? She’s just late. Have some mashed potatoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PAN across a PURPLE AND LAVENDER SUNSET and arrive at a WINDOW through which Rachel and Richard can be seen sitting in the same booth -- hours later.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: After all that, it was just like... Poof!

dialogues.speaker: A SKYPE SESSION --
dialogues.text: with Tiffany, which quickly dissolves into ANOTHER SESSIO and then ANOTHER...

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She never showed up and we never heard from her again. Tiffany’s image FREEZES and we DISSOLVE TO --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard and Rachel drive in silence. They pass signs for Clinton National Airport.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We'd been warned about this stuff. But she’d never asked us for money or anything, so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON an “I miss Bill” REFRIGERATOR MAGNET. A Clinton CHAIN. An “I Heart Little Rock” MUG. WIDER--our couple float aimlessly through A GIFT SHOP. Richard looks at RUBBER HALLOWEEN MASKS of Bill and Hilla Rachel stands in front of a POSTCARD CAROUSEL looking at picture of a young Hillary and Bill cradling newborn Chel A BOARDING ANNOUNCEMENT can be heard.

dialogues.speaker: LATER--
dialogues.text: Richard and Rachel pull rolling bags as they head toward Richard carries a shopping bag. As they walk into the dis we hear THE SOUND OF A PLANE TAKING OFF.  33

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SONOGRAMS on the refrigerator are being removed. Richard and Rachel, still in the same clothes from the trip, examine the flimsy print-outs.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When we got home, we realized... there was no name or date on any of the sonograms. SLOWLY PUSH IN ON the PHOTO OF TIFFANY held up by magnets

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Kyra said sometimes the girls just want the attention... and there isn’t a baby at all. The photo is plucked off the fridge. HOLD on empty space. We still don’t know if she was real or not. INT. RACHEL AND RICHARD’S APARTMENT - PRESENT Beth looks at the sonograms.

dialogues.speaker: BETH
dialogues.text: It’s much easier when it involves money. At least that makes some kind of sense. But the emotional scams... (shaking her head) After something like that, a lot of people give up -- or they throw themselves back on the fertility treadmill. It’s a real testament to your strength as a couple that you stuck with it and renewed your commitment to adoption. Rachel and Richard smile stiffly and nod. The SOUND OF THUNDER and HEAVY RAIN carries us to -- INT. RACHEL AND RICHARD’S APARTMENT - ANOTHER DAY (RAININ Rachel opens a KITCHEN CABINET, revealing an array of FERTILITY MEDICATION. She plucks a bottle from the shelf pops a pill into her mouth. Without swallowing, she retrieves one bottle after another, in quick succession, filling her mouth with pills. Finally, with a big swig of water, she knocks back all the pills in her mouth.  34 From another shelf, she removes a GREEN BAG, stuffs sever pills into PILL POCKETS and feeds one each to Eno and Laz who circle around her, panting.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Rachel sits on her bed surrounded by paper working on a B MANUSCRIPT filled with copy-editing marks and Post-its. S pauses and lays the manuscript on the bed so we can see t title page: WOMEN’S STUDIES by Rachel Biegler. Rachel sta into space for a moment, looking uneasy, then begins feel her breasts. She presses them to see if they are sore. Th are! INT. “THE PICKLE GUY” OFFICES - DAY (RAIN) Richard and his only employee, SAM (30), are in the middl of receiving a delivery of PICKLE GUY PRODUCTS. Sam is alone in the storage room when a message arrives on Richard’s phone. Sam picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Rich. Text from Rachel. Through the doorway, we see Richard out in the hall helpi TWO UPS GUYS unload dollies.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What does it say? Sam opens the message and blushes.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: It’s kind of personal. Sam holds up the phone so Richard can see -- A SELFIE OF RACHEL’S BREASTS, spilling from her bra with the caption: “Do these look bigger to you?” Richard cracks a tiny smile. CUT TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel emerges from a subway station, hurries down a street and arrives at a door with a bronze plaque: LAWRENCE DORDICK, MD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A NURSE wearing DEVIL HORNS draws Rachel’s blood.  35

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On her way out, Rachel passes the desk where FOUR WOMEN work at various stations. A JACK-O-LANTERN sits on the ledge along with a GOLDFISH BOWL FILLED WITH LOLLIPOPS. Rachel lingers, then takes a lollipop, pops it in her mouth and smiles at a receptionist, who smiles back. As Rachel pulls on her coat, she discovers that she’s standing in front of a wall covered in CHEERFUL CARDS and BIRTH ANNOUNCEMENTS. She begins reading the notes of appreciation and looking at the photos of babies and beaming children.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: We're rooting for you. Rachel turns to find one of the receptionists looking at with obvious empathy. INT. RACHEL AND RICHARD’S APARTMENT - DAY Rachel showers, letting the water pelt her face. In the distance, a PHONE RINGS. Richard enters the apartment with the dogs on leashes. Hearing the phone --

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Rache?! Richard drops the leashes and answers. Hello? Sure, hold on. Rache! He hurries into the bathroom. Rache. It’s Dordick. Rachel SHUTS OFF the water, pulls open the curtain and looks at her husband. Richard hands her a towel. She wraps herself in it and sits down on the side of the tub. Richard joins her. They look at each other, prepare themselves, then Richard pushes the SPEAKER button.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay. We’re both on.

dialogues.speaker: DORDICK, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hi, Rachel.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (tentative) Hi.  36 Excruciating silence.

dialogues.speaker: DORDICK, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: It’s not good news, guys. HOLD on our couple as the words sink in. INT. DOCTOR’S WAITING ROOM - DAY A WIRE MOBILE IN THE SHAPE OF A PREGNANT WOMAN dangles in front of a window. Caught in the stream of air coming fro nearby vent, the wire woman twists and turns, occasionall striking the window like a fly trying to escape. TAP. TAP TAP. WIDE -- Rachel and Richard sit among other couples ina cramped seating area. The room is hushed except for the sound of the TAPPING. INT. DORDICK’S INNER OFFICE - DAY Consulting his notes --

dialogues.speaker: DORDICK
dialogues.text: You could give it another go. This was your first IVF. Rachel responded well. It only takes one good egg. On the other hand, the two of you have been at it for quite some time and if money is a factor -- that combined with Rachel’s age makes me think... sure, you could try again, but your best chance of success is with a donor egg. Rachel and Richard are stunned. It’s a big leap, I know. It takes some getting used to. And I don’t want to diminish the loss of a genetic link for Rachel, but there are a lot of positives to consider. Rachel would carry the child. Control the pre-natal environment. Give birth, breast-feed. And, of course, there would be Richard's genetic contribution. (pause) It’s a lot to wrap your head around. Give it some time. Dordick takes out a brochure and slides it across the des (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 37 Meanwhile, take a look at our program. See what you think and we can talk next week. The couple looks at THE SHINY BROCHURE where ethnically diverse young women with good teeth smile up at them. Below the image, it says: Sometimes it takes three to make a family...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door to Dordick’s office is thrown open and Rachel hurls herself out. Richard follows -- brochure in hand, pulling on his coat -- and tries to catch up.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: He’s out of his fucking mind! There's no way in hell I’m doing that.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: We should at least just think about it. Rachel stops and turns to face him. I’m not saying we would do it. We can just... explore the idea. See how we feel. Make a list of all the pros and cons --

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (tentative) We’ve come this far. Rachel, flabbergasted, stares at her husband. What?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: We talked about this. We swore we would never do it.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: No. You swore you would never do it. I kept my mouth shut because I didn’t want to pressure you into something that you’re going to have to live with for the rest of your life.  38

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Wait. So all this time that I’ve been going along assuming that we feel the same way about this, you’ve been having secret fantasies about egg donation?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: It’s not a secret fantasy.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: It is to me. I didn’t know about it. I thought we decided together, as a couple that we would definitely draw the line at... science fiction!

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: It’s not science fiction, Rache. It’s pretty primitive, actually. They do it with farm animals all the time. Rachel’s jaw drops.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Well, I’m not a goat, okay?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Bad example. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh, my god. You're really freaking me out, right now. You’re so gung-ho.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I am not gung-ho. I’m... pragmatic. If we do another IVF with your eggs, we have, what? -- a four percent chance of getting pregnant? With a donor egg, we’d be going from four to like sixty-five percent. The gambler in me wants to put my money on the better odds. Rachel’s eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh, my god, you’re Guy Woodhouse.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: The husband in Rosemary’s Baby. John Cassavetes. That’s you.  39

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Yeah, Rachel. That’s me. Standing by while you're being raped by a satanic demon. I’m just suggesting we listen to our doctor and look into all the options. We’re already signed up for adoption, what’s the big deal?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Well, for one, I’m not putting someone else’s body parts into my uterus! A NANNY warily approaches with a double-wide stroller. Unable to pass, she gives them looks. Richard leads Rache a few steps to the side, smiling politely.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (hushed) I know it’s more complicated for you.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Isn't it more complicated for you, too?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Yes, of course, it is... But you heard him. There are lots of positives. (stroking her cheek) You'd get to carry the baby. Rachel swats his hand away.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh, woop-de-do! What does that make me? The bellhop?!

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (weak, barely audible) No. Richard, utterly at sea, watches his wife walk away until she whips around and hisses:

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Well, why don’t you just go screw a younger woman, then?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What’re you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh, look. There’s one now. She points to a thirty-ish woman walking on the other sid of the street.  40 Go fuck her!

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I don’t want to fuck her! The woman in question glances over, picking up her pace. Rachel marches away again. Richard goes after her. Look, we’re doing just about everything we can short of kidnapping to start a family. I don't know why this is so off limits. Rachel staggers to a halt and looks at her husband.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Easy for you to say. You... (voice catching) You'll have your... genetic contribution. Me, I'll just be... A spasm of shallow breaths overtake her.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (soft) What?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: ---11111... left out... Rachel erupts into tears. Richard watches her for a moment, then goes to hug her but is met with Rachel's wrath as she starts pounding on his chest. Keeping his face out of the line of fire, he opens his coat and manages to wrap Rachel inside even as she continues to pound. Finally exhausted, her body goes limp and she allows herself to be comforted. They stand on the sidewalk -- pressed together under the -- as pedestrians walk around them. Leaves fall from the trees. We see a TRICK-OR-TREATER or two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More trick-or-treaters: BLOODIED GHOULS and FACE-PAINTED BUTTERFLIES. Parents are dressed up, too. A BANNER reads NEIGHBORHOOD SCHOOL HALLOWEEN PARADE. A motley MARCHING BAND of aging punk rock parents plays MUSIC as it leads the procession.  41 INT. RACHEL AND RICHARD’S APARTMENT - CONTINUOUS The distant marching band can be heard as Richard and Rachel nap with their dogs. A loud, unpleasant BUZZZZ wakes them, and Richard gets up to go to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GRIM REAPER (10) and a BALLERINA (7) wait in the hall.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (groggy) Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (whispering) The kids from the third floor.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: What do they want?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (is she kidding?) Candy. It’s Halloween.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (whispering) Oh, shit. Right. Just don’t answer it. There is a sudden KNOCK and Rachel and Richard stand ther frozen. Muffled voices can be heard through the door.

dialogues.speaker: BALLERINA GIRL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Someone’s there. I heard them.

dialogues.speaker: GRIM REAPER
dialogues.text: Maybe, but they’re not answering.

dialogues.speaker: BALLERINA
dialogues.text: But it’s a holiday.

dialogues.speaker: GRIM REAPER
dialogues.text: It’s not that kind of holiday. Not everybody celebrates Halloween. Especially people that don’t have kids. The boy walks down the hall while his sister lingers. INT. RACHEL AND RICHARD’S APARTMENT - CONTINUOUS Richard and Rachel stand there, listening.  42

dialogues.speaker: BALLERINA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They did it last year. FADE OUT. INT. RICHARD AND RACHEL’S APARTMENT - ANOTHER NIGHT A COMPUTER SCREEN where little HEAD-SHOTS of young women scroll past, accompanied by ID NUMBERS and short descriptions: --24 year-old (Italian; Irish) 5'6”, brown eyes, fair ski -22 year-old (Russian born) 5'’4”, hazel eyes, brown hair --26 year-old (Brazilian born; US citizen) brown hair, brown eyes.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Jesus. It’s like eBay for ova. WIDER reveals Rachel stretched out on the living room cou with her laptop open, calling into another room. There’s one that got a full athletic scholarship in golf. She gets up and walks to -- THE BEDROOM -- where Richard lounges with a book. Have you ever even heard of that? College golf?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I thought you were working on your edit. Rachel joins him on the bed and turns her laptop so he ca see.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: What d’you think? Do you want her to have your baby? Richard ignores the computer.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: She's not having my baby. You are.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Okay. Fine. But what d’you think? Richard puts his book down and gives the laptop his full attention.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I think she’s fine.  43

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: That’s all you have to say?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I’m not gonna make a big deal about it. It’s just an egg. It’s one cell. Richard resumes reading.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (mumbling to herself) One cell that contains half the chromosomes of our child-to-be.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I don’t see it that way. Rachel laughs and shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh, my god, you are so in denial it’s crazy.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Don’t knock denial. It comes in very handy. You should try it sometime. Without it, you end up like this guy. He holds up his book, THE STRUGGLE, so Rachel can see the intense face of the Norwegian author on the cover. Rachel snort-laughs, then returns to looking at her screen.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Listen to this. Double major in philosophy and political science at an East Coast Ivy League University. Entered at 16.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Too intimidating.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Your sperm might be very shy around her eggs. Richard gives up trying to read and scoots closer to the screen. Richard grimaces at something.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Favorite book: “The Fountainhead.”

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh... see that asterisk? That means she’s reserved. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 44 There’s probably a waiting list. It’s the Ivy League thing. Richard points to an attractive young woman with brown ha

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Click on her. She’s cute. Rachel clicks the thumbnail and a page opens with a longe description and additional photos.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: She has a BA. Majored in journalism and cinema studies. No wonder she’s selling her eggs. She can’t get a job. I like her nose.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I like your nose. Richard kisses Rachel’s cheek, then buries his face in th crook of her neck. Mmm. This is kind of kinky. Rachel giggles and squirms, then notices something out of the corner of her eye.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh, my god. Richard. She points and Richard leans in to look at ANOTHER YOUNG WOMAN, this one with auburn hair.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Wait. Is that... Fiona? From Mogador? Rachel nods, almost imperceptibly. Whoa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The real-life FIONA glides through the restaurant. She talks easily with some customers, writing their order on pad. The camera lingers. Rachel and Richard sit at a table with their menus and coffee, watching.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I don’t know. This is weird.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Think of it like an exercise. There’s no right or wrong answers.  45

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Alright. Fine. (surreptitiously looking) Well. She’s beautiful. That's obvious. And she’s always nice, which is good. Any time we come in. No matter how crowded. She’s got a great laugh and an amazing body. In the summer when she wears those thin cotton dresses with her hair all piled up...

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You're not supposed to think about how hot she is, Richard. You're not going to have sex with her. Rachel sighs, looks away and shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What? You said there were no wrong answers. It’s very confusing. I’ve never done this before.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Neither have I. But just... stop thinking about fucking her, okay. Think about her like she’s your daughter. Not your girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: God.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (eyes pooling) Nothing. He reaches across the table and lays his hand on her fore

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I love you. She takes her arm back and gazes down at the table. You’re the one who wanted to do this.  46

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh, do you think I enjoy this? Looking for another woman’s egg to mix with my husband’s sperm so I can inject it into my uterus so we can have a baby? Richard notices A COUPLE at a nearby table look over. At least Fiona is a flesh and blood person we actually know, instead of some random thumbnail photo. (an exhale, then--) Maybe we should just ask her. Rachel raises her arm to flag Fiona. Richard yanks it dow clanking the cutlery and water glasses in the process.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Are you crazy? We can’t ask her.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: She put her picture up on a website.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: That doesn’t mean she wants customers inquiring about her ovaries during the brunch rush-

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hi, guys. Rachel and Richard turn to find Fiona looking down at the with a warm smile, pen and pad in hand. What can I get you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The couple make their way through the cluster of customer on the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (pulling on her coat) Oh, god. It’s like The Handmaid’s Tale. It would be different if I had like... a younger sister or cousin or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard’s cell RINGS. As they walk, he digs through the pockets of the coat slung over his arm. Even a family friend. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 47 Someone in our lives who we had a real connection with -- so I wasn’t just preying on the ovarian reserves of random young women... Rachel, realizing that Richard is no longer walking beside her, turns to find him staring at his phone.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What? Richard shows her the phone: SADIE BENNET. Rachel realize what he must be thinking and they lock eyes -- each silently turning over the same idea. The RINGING PHONE goes SILENT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SADIE, in profile, looking out the passenger seat window.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It really sucks what you’ve been going through.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. It does. Thanks. Another ANGLE shows Richard, behind the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Thanks?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: For confirming that my life sucks right now. It really means a lot to me.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You’re welcome.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: I know you’re technically just my step uncle and aunt, but I feel closer to you guys than everyone else in the family. You guys get it. Everyone else is on me all the time to get my shit together. Like I’m some sort of drop-out or something. Pause.  48

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You did just drop out of Bard, didn’t you?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: No. I was granted permission by the Dean’s Office to finish my degree requirements in absentia. That's a thing.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: It’s Latin, right? For dropped out? Sadie playfully swipes at Richard.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Hey, watch it. I’m driving. She looks out the window and shakes her head --

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: God. Even you, Uncle Cool.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Hey. You came up with that name, not me. The idea that anyone would refer to me as “cool” is just evidence of how utterly uncool our family is. Sadie laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard’s old Subaru whizzes by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard drives, listening to Duke Ellington. Sadie is asleep. The MANHATTAN SKYLINE appears and Richard taps he She opens her eyes and groggily, but in awe, takes in the sparkling view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the window: Avenue A is crawling with young peopl out for a good time. As the car pulls up to his apartment building, Richard is distressed to find FRESH GRAFFITI, a DRUNK passed out and SHADY GUY smoking in front of the neighboring LIQUOR STOR  49

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: I thought everything was supposed to be all gentrified now.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, I guess they forgot about our corner.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: It’s so... Serpico. INT. RACHEL AND RICHARD’S APARTMENT - NIGHT Richard holds the door open for Sadie who teeters in wearing a massive backpack. The two dogs rush toward her.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Oh, my god! Sadie kneels down to greet them. Rachel emerges from an adjoining room, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Hi, Sade. Sadie jumps up and throws her arms around Rachel, but her enthusiasm, combined with her unwieldy backpack, knock th off balance. They topple over, sending the dogs into a fi of barking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard, Rachel and Sadie sit at a booth in a crowded Italian restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: So, how do you plan on finishing? Sadie tears bread and dips it in olive oil. Her chin is s

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Online.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Really? Why online?  Pause. 50

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: (between bites) Because that way I don’t have to talk to any deluded college students who think the real world actually gives a shit about their stupid short fiction -- which isn’t even really “fiction” in the first place, just thinly veiled autobiographical crap about their entitled upbringings. (waiter brings plates) Mmm. Thanks. And I won’t have to listen to what a big deal it is that they’re being published in some random literary magazine that no one has ever even heard of... like Tin House or whatever.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Wait. Tin House?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Tin House is a really well-regarded literary magazine.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: They published something of yours, right?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Once. Yeah. (to Sadie) Everybody at your school is getting published in Tin House?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Not everybody. I just mean, in general, it’s like everyone is so self-promoting and convinced of their own artistic promise and I’m like, hey, my uncle is an award-winning theater genius and my aunt is a real- life playwright and author who gets her stories published in well-known periodicals that normal people have actually heard of like The New Yorker, for instance. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 51 And they're over 40 and still have to live in a rent stabilized apartment on Avenue A with like drunks and graffiti in front. So don’t talk to me about the sacrifices you’re making to be an artist, okay? Rachel and Richard stare at Sadie with stiff smiles.

dialogues.speaker: A SERIES OF PHOTOS.
dialogues.text: -- RICHARD AND RACHEL, ten years younger, stand among company members in front of a run-down building with a ha painted sign that says “La Rata Theater.” -- RICHARD DIRECTS A REHEARSAL in a beat-up work space wi exposed brick and scaffolding. -- A PRODUCTION STILL from a gritty looking theater piece Bare stage. Shirtless men. -- ANOTHER PRODUCTION PHOTO IN BLACK & WHITE. A man and woman in a bed on a dramatically lit stage. A WIDE SHOT reveals we are back in -- INT. RICHARD AND RACHEL’S APARTMENT - NIGHT Sadie, wearing an over-sized Pickle Guy t-shirt, is looki at the photos on a wall of bookshelves in the living room Richard sits on the floor trying to blow up an air mattre without the aid of a pump.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Don’t you ever miss it? You guys were so great. Removing his mouth from the valve --

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Tell that to the N.E.A. Richard resumes blowing as Rachel drifts in with sheets and pillows.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, I meant to tell you. I walked by our old space on Walker Street the other day. You know what it is now? A Citibank. Just try doing Growtowski in front of an ATM. Rachel laughs. Sadie reads from a NEWSPAPER CLIPPING.  52

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: This was the year that a small downtown theater collective reminded us of the singular power of theater to astonish. In “Tray,” a story set among cafeteria workers in a suburban high school, La Rata and it’s director, Richard Grimes created a political comedy that deftly examines the racial and socioeconomic divide that plague our nation.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Who wrote that?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Jonathan Gilmore. The Village Voice.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: See. That’s how sad we are. We're from a time when the Village Voice was considered relevant.

dialogues.speaker: LATER, IN THE BATHROOM --
dialogues.text: As Rachel brushes her teeth, she notices Sadie’s TOILETRY BAG. After a quick glance at the door, she begins to dig through the contents: “Wet ‘n’ Wild Lip Gloss,” Pink disposable razors. Deep Cleaning Pore Strips. Rachel abruptly stops rifling and stares dumbstruck when she com across a package of “Plan B” morning-after pills. Just th Sadie walks in, startling Rachel who swings around and kn the bag to the floor. The toiletries spill out and roll around.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (mouth full of toothpaste) Oh, shit. Sorry. I got it.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: That’s okay. I can do it. Rachel frantically shoves the toiletries into the bag, sp out her toothpaste, and rushes out, leaving Sadie bewilde

dialogues.speaker: LATER --
dialogues.text: Rachel and Richard lie in bed flanked by their dogs. Rich is asleep, but not Rachel.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (whispering) Honey? Honey, are you awake? No response. She softly pokes his shoulder.  53 Richard?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Huh? What?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Do you think we should do it?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Ask Sadie. She heaves a big sigh and stares up at the ceiling. She’s so young. Richard looks blearily at his worried wife.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: That's the point, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SERIES of SHOTS: Rooftops in the early morning. On the last one, we tilt down to find Sadie smoking on a fire es with bare legs, unlaced sneakers and a big down jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel is at the counter grinding coffee beans and making cappuccinos on their semi-professional machine. As espres oozes, she looks out the window at Sadie on the fire esca Rachel studies her, then turns to Richard, already sittin the table with his own coffee. They look at each other, t Richard nods. She turns back to the window, knocks on it holds up A MUG printed with the word “Yaddo.” Sadie smiles, stubs out her cigarette and climbs back int the kitchen to find her cappuccino sitting on the table along with toast, jam and a newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Wow. How Instagrammable. Thank you. (tasting her coffee) Mmm. Yum. Rachel picks up her own mug as does Richard, and there’s long pause as everyone sips silently. Then -- SADIE (CONT’D) Oh, my god. Look at us. We’re like an ad for assholes.  54 Sadie laughs and wipes her mouth with the back of her hand. Rachel and Richard smile vaguely.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You mean, we’re assholes? Or we’re part of an ad that’s targeted to assholes?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: No. It’s just, you know. That whole-- (sing-songy pizzicato delivery) People. With cappuccinos. In their lofts. With their laptops and their dogs. With messy hair. (regular voice) That whole fantasy... It’s not your fault. You guys are authentic and real. You’ve just been co- opted by the cultural mechanisms that create desirability. Richard and Rachel smile and nod vaguely. I took a Media and Consumer Society course. It was pretty life-altering. Another pause as everyone sips. Then Rachel throws Richar glance, and he takes his cue.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Uh, Sadie, -- (clears his throat) -- there's something that we want to, um... Richard hesitates, then gets the ball rolling, so to spea You know I only have one testicle, right? Taken aback, Sadie looks at her uncle, then Rachel, then back to Richard.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah, actually. I do.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You do?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Charlie mentioned it once.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: He did?  55

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Not to me, personally. But to my mom. I overheard it. A couple of Thanksgivings ago. I can’t remember. Whenever you guys were going through all that fertility stuff.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: We're still going through all that fertility stuff.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: I thought my mom said you guys were trying to adopt.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Yeah. We are. But... recently we decided that it might be a good idea to try everything all at once because... Well, we’re not getting any younger...

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: That’s for sure. Rachel and Richard laugh lamely. Sadie smiles, not sure w

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: And we just had a failed IVF.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Wait. What?! Oh, my god. You guys. I’m so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: That must suck. Rachel and Richard smile sadly. It’s not over, is it? I mean, you're going to keep trying, right?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
