dialogues.text: (a quick glance at Rachel) Well, now the doctor is suggesting a different approach altogether, SO...

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Oh, my god. My mom said that you guys had a lot going on, but I had no idea. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 56 This is a really bad time for me to be crashing here, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Not at all. It’s great.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Really? Because I have friends in Bushwick...

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD RACHEL
dialogues.text: No way. No. We’re really glad you’re here.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: You're sure?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Rachel reaches for Sadie’s hand and squeezes it.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Me, too. (choking up) I love you guys. Sadie puts down her coffee and reaches for Richard’s hand so all three of them are holding hands. An awkward pause. Then --

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I’m gonna pop in some more toast.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Good idea. Rachel lets go and pulls a loaf of bread out of the fridg Sadie spots the Magazine Section and pulls it out of the

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Ooooo. (turning to the last page) Does anybody mind if I get started on the crossword? As Sadie finds a pen and pulls the cap off with her teeth Rachel catches Richard's eye. He nods and composes himsel

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Actually... we wanted to ask you about your eggs.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Scrambled is good. But however you guys do them is fine with me.  57 Richard and Rachel stare at an oblivious Sadie, who chomp on toast as she fills in a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard, along with Eno and Lazlo, escort Sadie down an industrial hallway. They arrive at the PICKLE GUY OFFICES just as the door opens. Sam is preparing to roll out a dolly stacked with BOXES OF PICKLES and BALES OF HAY.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Oh, hey.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Hey. (suddenly self-conscious) Or did you mean, “hay?” (gesturing to the bales) With an A?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: No. Just, “hey” as in hello. Sam, this is my niece, Sadie. Sadie, Sam. They exchange hellos. Sadie is going to help out around here for a while. I thought you could show her the ropes. Sam finds Sadie very attractive, but maintains his composure.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yeah. Okay. Cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sadie kneels inside the back of a VAN as Sam hands her bo

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I like to be as prepared as possible the night before The Farmer's Market because we set up at 5:00 am. And at that hour I’m utterly impaired and not ina position to make any kind of business decision. I am definitely not a morning person. What about you?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: What?  58

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Are you a morning person?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: I guess so. I like the morning. The before-ness of it all. It feels optimistic. Fresh. Optimism doesn’t come that naturally to me, so I need to grab whatever positive free vibes I can get. Sadie laughs at herself. Sam just stares at her, entranced. After several seconds, Sadie gestures for a box. Sam snaps out of it and hands her one. As she slides the box deeper into the van, he can’t help but notice Sadie’s thong underwear peeking out over the top o her jeans. Sadie turns back for another box and catches Sam looking. Oh, my god. I’m totally whale- tailing, aren’t I? Sorry. Sam continues to stare as she good-naturedly hitches up her pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard emerges with BAGS OF TAKE-OUT and joins Rachel, S and the dogs out front. They begin walking when Sadie loo up at something and then stops.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Oh, my god. What does that even mean? THEIR POV -- A GIANT SIGN on top of a building advertisin new high-rise apartments. It says: LIVE LIKE A ROCKEFELLE

dialogues.speaker: SADIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s like an open invitation to assholes. Sadie snaps a picture with her cellphone. INT. RACHEL AND RICHARD’S APARTMENT - NIGHT Rachel, Richard and Sadie eat with chopsticks.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Oh, my god, my esophagus is on fucking fire! I love this. Rachel and Richard smile and nod in agreement. Then Richard gets down to business.  59

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Sadie... Rachel and I have been looking for an egg donor. Do you know what that is? Sadie looks up from her food, a little thrown.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah. I do. They advertise at school. I know somebody who did it, actually. A film major. They paid her like ten thousand dollars. That’s how she financed her senior thesis. It was the entire budget of her short film. She called her company “Ovum Productions.” Sadie lets out small propulsive laugh, then regrets it. It was funny at the time... not so much now...

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD RACHEL
dialogues.text: No. It is... Yeah. It’s funny. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: We wanted to ask you about your eggs, actually.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: In your ovaries.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: (tentative) Oh. Okay. What about them? Richard looks at Rachel, then back to Sadie.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Uh. Well... We were wondering... if you might... consider... donating some.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: To us.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Just like your friend.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Except not.  Pause. 60

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Yeah. Right. Because... you know us, so it would be different.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: (softly to herself) Wow.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: What does it involve, exactly?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Well. Technically, you’d be going through pretty much what I just went through with IVF. Minus the transfer.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: What’s the transfer?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: It’s when they put the fertilized eggs back into your uterus.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: My. Uterus. In this case.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Right. Yeah. It wouldn’t be yours because... it would be Rachel’s... so... your uterus wouldn’t be involved in this instance. You'd be done right after the retrieval.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You'd have to be screened by the clinic, first.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: They'd give you a bunch of blood tests. A psychiatric evaluation.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: (nervous laugh) Uh-oh...

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: No, it’s not like that. They just want to make sure you’re able to handle the whole thing. Psychologically.  61

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Right, so I don’t go all -- (widening her eyes) -- Mary Beth Whitehead on you. Sadie wiggles her fingers and does a crazy laugh, then immediately regrets it.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Uh, nothing. Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Who is that, again?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Just something we read about in a Medical Ethics class. (off their puzzled look) The surrogate in the Baby M. case. In the eighties.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: She refused to give up the baby or something, right?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sorry. Creepy reference. Totally inappropriate.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Okay. So... What else?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: The drugs.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Right, of course. The stimulating hormones. How could I forget. You give yourself injections to increase your egg count for the cycle.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: It’s a lot of shots. Rachel lifts up her shirt, exposing her fading bruises.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Oh, my god.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: It looks a lot worse than it is. But the drugs can make you feel pretty crazy mood-wise. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My shrink had a funny name for it. (to Richard) What did she call it, again?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Emotionally incontinent.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: (laughing) Oh, my god. Gross.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: But because it’s not you who’s trying to have the baby -- (nervous glance to Rachel) -- directly. It’1ll be way less fraught. Emotionally. (to Rachel) Don’t you think?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Definitely.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: And, of course, we’d pay you.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: What?! No, way! I’m not taking money from you guys.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: No. We insist. We want to pay you exactly what you’d get if you did it at any of the university clinics. Eight thousand dollars, just like your friend. It’s not a lot of money, considering, but it’s the standard rate and it’s all we can afford. A pause as Sadie sits there, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You don’t have to tell us anything now. Richard pulls out the donor brochure, gives it to

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: It’s just an overview. It’s a lot to absorb. Take your time and think it over. 62 Sadie. Sadie stares at the women on the brochure’s cover, then  63 Sadie reads a bit, then closes the brochure.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Good. (rubbing his hands together) All right, who needs more beer?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (raising her hand) I do.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: No. I mean, okay. Yes. I'11 do it. (off their confused look) The egg thing. I’1l do it.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh, no. You don’t have to You really need to take some give us an answer now. time to think about it. It’s a big decision.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Why? I’m totally cool with it. Rachel and Richard are clearly freaked out by the speed of Sadie’s decision. Really. It’s not like I’m doing anything else right now. I don’t even have a job. And what could be more rewarding than helping two people I love start a family? (voice breaking) You guys have always been such role models for me. You’re so supportive and non-judgmental. You’re going to be such amazing parents. Way better than mine.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: That’s not true. You have great parents. Sadie rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: We'll need to talk to them about it, too, you know. It has to all be out in the open. Totally transparent.  64

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: I don’t see a problem with that.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You don’t?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Nah. My mom is all about me finding a purpose and doing something “real” with my life. Sadie picks up the brochure and waves it around. Welp. It doesn’t get more real than this, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sadie’s head sticks out of the SUN ROOF of the Subaru as speeds along. Her hair whips around as she films the sky her CELLPHONE CAMERA. THROUGH SADIE’S CAMERA: SUN, TREE TOPS, SKY rush by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel rides shotgun. Sadie stands in the back between th dogs. Spirits are high as they listen to music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOGS run through PILES OF LEAVES as Richard throws a with his CHUCK-IT device. THROUGH SADIE’S CAMERA: the threesome runaround being chased by Eno and Lazlo. The wo bury Richard in LEAVES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WOOSH! The car is back on the road, going even faster. INT. CHARLIE’S HOUSE - DAY Charlotte sits on her bed with her laptop, surrounded by homework. At the sound of a car arriving, she gets up and goes to -- THE WINDOW, where she sees the Subaru pulling up out fron

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: They’re here! Charlotte dashes out of the room, but the CAMERA remains the window as the car doors open and the dogs leap out.  65 EXT. CHARLIE’S HOUSE - DAY Charlotte runs to greet Sadie, jumping up on her for a pi back ride. Cynthia and Charlie step out to welcome their guests, Cha gives Richard a hug. Meanwhile, Sadie drags an OVER-STUFFED LAUNDRY BAG from t

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: You brought laundry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FLURRY OF LEAVES soars into the air, accompanied by a H PITCHED WHINE. Charlie is demonstrating his new gas-power LEAF-BLOWER to Richard. At an opportune moment, Richard slips something into Charlie’s shirt pocket. Charlie pulls it out and unfolds It’s a check for $5,000.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I’ll get you the rest before the end of the year. Charlie looks into his brother’s eyes. Richard smiles sad and they hug, leaves swirling around them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tears stream down Rachel and Cynthia’s faces. Are they having a heart-to-heart? Nope, they’re just chopping onio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sadie stares at an AUTUMNAL CENTERPIECE on the table.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: God, I hate gourds. She removes the centerpiece, shakes open a table cloth an lets it float down onto the table. Nearby, Charlotte pull dishes out of a cabinet. She yells into the kitchen --

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Mom, how many?

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How many what?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: People. Are eating?  66

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cars pull up as more guests arrive with foil-covered plat There are hugs and kisses. We catch bits and pieces of conversations. Some people carry wine glasses as they dri about. Kids run around. A teenager plays piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The table is crowded with family and friends. Charlie cli glass with a knife. Everyone quiets as Cynthia stands.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Charlie and I decided that we wanted to do Thanksgiving right for a change. So before we dig in we'd like to go around the table and invite everyone to talk about what they are thankful for this year. There are a few groans from the guests. C’mon. Please. I’m going to start. (raising her wine glass) I’m thankful for Richard and Rachel -- Sadie hoots and raises her glass; she’s already had a few Our couple is surprised by the attention. --for taking such good care of our daughter Sadie, and giving her a great home-base in Manhattan, where she has the love and support she needs in order to begin her new life there. (addressing them directly) I know it has been a tough time for you guys. And the fact that you are taking care of someone else’s child when you're struggling to have one of your own is just more evidence of your incredible generosity. I hope some day we can repay you for all that you’ve done.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Here, here. Everyone toasts Rachel and Richard, who blush humbly. Rac blinks to hold back tears.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Can I be next?

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Sure, honey. Go ahead.  Cynthia sits down and Sadie stands up.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Okay. That was beautiful and it’s the perfect prologue for what I wanted to say. I’m also thankful to Rachel and Richard for all they’ve done for me over the years. From letting me intern at their theater company...

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Free labor is more like it...

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: ...to employing me at the Pickle Guy offices. And most recently, letting me crash at their place until I get my act together. I’m especially thankful to you, Rachel, for reading all my lame attempts at play-writing and short fiction. Rachel flicks her hand and shakes her head. And for taking me seriously as an artist when I have such a hard time doing it myself. And finally, this seems like the perfect occasion to share some exciting news. I’m going rogue here, I haven't cleared this with Rachel and Richard, but I can’t let this moment go to waste. 67 Rachel and Richard’s smiles dissolve as it dawns on them Sadie is preparing to say. Cynthia’s jaw drops open as she comes to a different conclusion. She catches Rachel’s eye and mouths to her: you pregnant?” Rachel shakes her head. Richard speaks up, but not with enough force to stop this runaway train.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Uh, Sadie, I’m not sure this is...

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: (misunderstanding, smiling) No, it’s okay. (back to the group) See, the thing I’m most thankful for this year is the opportunity to help Richard and Rachel...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “Are  68

dialogues.speaker: SADIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -- make their dreams come No... Sadie... really, don’t. true...

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: (waving him off) By offering just a tiny bit of myself, I get to give these guys the greatest gift they could have asked for. The gift of life. An oocyte. Silence as Sadie beams proudly. Many of the guests look around, unclear about what has just been said. Rachel and Richard stare down at the table, dreading what’s coming.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: I don’t understand. What’s an oocyte?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: Isn't it like an egg?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: That's right. I’ve decided to be Richard and Rachel’s egg donor. Cynthia’s face darkens. There are uncomprehending murmurs among the guests. And if all goes well, next year we'll be giving thanks for the newest member of our family... (raising her glass) Richard and Rachel’s baby. The murmurs stop. Everyone at the table stares at Sadie until an ELDERLY WOMAN begins to applaud. Cynthia shoots the woman a look, but other guests are already joining in the whole table is now toasting and cheering. Richard and Rachel sit in shock as they get their backs slapped by nearby guests and others congratulate them. Cynthia grabs Sadie by the elbow and pulls her into the k Meanwhile, UNCLE BOB (65) taps his glass with his spoon.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE BOB
dialogues.text: It’s my turn, now, right? As Uncle Bob stands, we hear voices coming from the kitch

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Over my dead body! Do you hear me?  69

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: This has nothing to do with your body. It’s my body --

dialogues.speaker: SADIE CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: -- and I can do whatever I This isn’t giving blood or want with it. checking the organ donation box on your goddamn driver's license.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard and Rachel sit uncomfortably among the guests who help but overhear the argument as Uncle Bob finishes his

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You'll be living with this the rest of your life. Our whole family will be affected by it.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’ve given it a lot of thought.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh, have you?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes, I have. I want to help them. It means a lot to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the women argue, Cynthia removes items from the oven.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Well, now it’s fun. You get to be the center of attention. But what about after the baby is born? What then?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I’11 be Aunt Sadie. Or cousin Sadie or whatever they want me to be. Look, mom. What if you had kidney disease? And I was your friend and I had two kidneys. A person only needs one kidney, right? So I’ve got an extra one. Of course, I'd give it to you.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Honey, kidney disease kills people. Rachel wants to have a baby. She’s not dying.  70

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: How do you know?! Charlie enters carrying the turkey platter, followed by Richard and Rachel.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Cynthia. We were planning to talk to you about this.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s nice. And how are you planning on paying for it, Kickstarter?!

dialogues.speaker: SADIE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Jesus, mom! (to Cynthia) Honey, why don’t we go upstairs and you can take half of something.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Who’s side are you on?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE RACHEL
dialogues.text: Nobodys. We're not going through with it without your support.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Well, you don’t have it. Cynthia locates an ELECTRIC KNIFE and begins carving turk

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE CYNTHIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Richard and Rachel) (to Sadie) Maybe it’s best if you guys just grab some food and go. We can talk about this later. Where are you going? Sadie has opened the basement door and is heading downsta

dialogues.speaker: SADIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m getting my laundry. Cynthia hands Charlie the knife and heads after her daugh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sadie marches to the dryer with Cynthia right behind her.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: God. You are so anti-Aunt Rachel.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: I’m not anti anybody.  Sadie opens the dryer and begins yanking out laundry and stuffing it into a bag.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Oh, c’mon, mom. On some level you're threatened by her. Is it because she’1ll have a book and a baby and you’1l have nothing once Charlotte’s gone? Cynthia stands there blinking.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: That's what you think I’m worried about? I’m worried about you. You could be squandering your future fertility for all you know. My god, you should be freezing your eggs, not selling them.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: That’s absurd. Tons of girls do it and they're fine. Anyway, I’m not having kids.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: You don’t know that now.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Yes I do. I don’t want kids. I want a career.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: You can have both. (off Sadie’s amused look) What?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Do you know how many times you’ve told me that women make sacrifices when they have kids? That you had to drop out of school when you had me. (beat) Look, every month I get my period and flush an egg down the toilet. Why not give some to Richard and Rachel instead? What could be more meaningful than giving two people I love who are desperate to start a family the gift of life?

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Oh, my god. They’ve brain-washed you. 71  72

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: (storming up the stairs) Why do you feel so cheated by life, mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard and Rachel are buckling their seat-belts. Through the window, they see Sadie hurrying toward the car with Cynthia right behind her.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Maybe we should've gone with an anonymous donor. In the background, some dinner guests roam the lawn like Thanksgiving refugees. Sadie throws her laundry in the hatchback and SLAMS it shut. Cynthia stops some distance away and shouts at Richard and Rachel.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: I know you want a child, but this is my child we’re talking about.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: I am not a child! Sadie climbs in the backseat with the dogs. Richard turns the headlights and starts the engine.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: If she was your daughter would you want her to do this? Before Rachel or Richard can respond, Charlie arrives wit some foil covered plates that he hands to Richard through the window. Then he puts his arm around Cynthia and waves smiling falsely...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming, guys. Good night! Richard backs out just as Charlotte joins her parents. Through the windshield, from Rachel’s POV, the shell-shoc family recedes from view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our trio rides in gloomy silence, lost in thought. The on sound is the HYPNOTIC THUD of tires on road seams. Dordic voice intrudes while the camera visits each of them.  73

dialogues.speaker: DORDICK, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: Third-party reproduction is usually an arrangement among anonymous or unrelated individuals, but some couples prefer to involve a family member or a trusted friend, which is fine. POINT OF VIEW traveling forward, mist in the headlights.

dialogues.speaker: DORDICK, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: As long as the people involved are mature consenting adults, it shouldn’t be a problem... INT. DORDICK’S WAITING ROOM - DAY Our threesome sit side-by-side on a couch. Unlike the wel heeled medical consumers surrounding them, they look like anxious kids waiting outside the principals office. INT. DORDICK’S OFFICE - DAY Rachel, Richard and Sadie sit opposite Dordick.

dialogues.speaker: DORDICK
dialogues.text: Now that’s not to say that this kind of collaboration doesn’t bring up some intense feelings for everyone, including the extended family. of course it does. This is uncharted territory for most people. But we’re getting ahead of ourselves. We don’t even know if Sadie’s an appropriate candidate for egg donation. Dordick’s speech continues over -- A MONTAGE, following Sadie through her screening process INT. DORDICK’S - VARIOUS ROOMS - DAY Sadie, in a gown, is weighed by a NURSE; she has her bloo pressure measured, her blood drawn.

dialogues.speaker: DORDICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My advice is get the process started and use the time to try and wrap your head around what this arrangement will mean for you and your family.  74

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BATHROOM --
dialogues.text: Sadie pees on the toilet. She pulls a cup from between he legs, screws on the lid and places it on a shelf in front of a SMALL METAL DOOR. The door opens, startling Sadie, and a woman’s hand snatches the cup.

dialogues.speaker: IN AN EXAM ROOM --
dialogues.text: Sadie has her feet in stirrups as Dordick performs a sono

dialogues.speaker: DR. DORDICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Then, after the lab results and the reports come back and Sadie’s completed her psychological evaluation, you can sit down and make a fully informed decision...

dialogues.speaker: IN ANOTHER ROOM --
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON A BOOKLET with a dull blue cover: Standard Multiform Psychiatric Evaluation. A hand opens the bookle to uncover a TRUE OR FALSE TEST. WIDER shows Sadie taking the test, filling in bubbles on answer sheet. CLOSE on one of the true or false statements: I am sure I get a raw deal from life. Sadie thinks, then fills in the bubble marked “False.” CLOSE on another statement: I am very seldom troubled by constipation. Sadie looks at the question, disconcerted, then answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evil spirits possess me at times. I would like to be a singer. No one seems to understand me. Sadie flips through the booklet and finds HUNDREDS of sim statements, including the FINAL ONE: At times I feel like smashing things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie in sports-goggles SMASHES the ball against the wa Richard returns it, and we watch the brothers play a vigo game of racquetball.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: I call him Uncle Richard but actually he’s my stepfather Charlie’s brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sadie talks to a FEMALE PSYCHOLOGIST, who takes notes.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: So we’re not really related... which is probably better for something like this... An uncomfortable pause as the psychologist stops writing looks over the top of her glasses at Sadie.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHOLOGIST
dialogues.text: Because otherwise it would be incest. A moment as Sadie puts this together.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Right. There’s that. So...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie and Richard guzzle water.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: For the record, I don’t have a problem with the whole donor thing. Richard looks at Charlie, surprised. That’s not to say I don’t think it’s a little weird -- it is. But, hey... I’m a periodontist -- I graft freeze-dried cadaver bone into the mouths of living people every day. I can handle weird. Cynthia is different. She’s much more... sensitive. Especially these days. She’s been having a really tough time -- hormonally.  76 INT. CHARLIE’S HOUSE - BATHROOM - NIGHT Cynthia stands at a MAGNIFYING MIRROR, moving her finger across her jaw, feeling something. She leans in and lifts her chin. IN THE MIRROR, her magnified chin sprouts ONE BRISTLY HAI Cynthia locates some TWEEZERS and tries to grab the offen hair. Her first attempt fails, so she tries again, pullin her lips into her mouth. GOT IT! She holds the tweezers up to examine the wiry whisker, th notices a PIN-SIZED DROP OF BLOOD on her chin. She grabs some toilet paper and dabs at it. INT. CHARLIE’S HOUSE - BEDROOM - NIGHT Charlie reads in bed as Cynthia rubs lotion on her legs.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (eyes on his book) I saw Richard today.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: He’s good.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: He says Sadie’s doing a great job at the Pickle Guy offices. Maybe you should give her a call. (hesitant) ...they’re screening her.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: (looking up) Who’s screening her?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The clinic. For the egg donation. Cynthia stares at her husband, then returns to moisturizi Maybe you want to talk to her about it.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: She doesn’t need my permission.  77

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That’s true. She doesn’t. She’s hell-bent on the idea no matter what anyone says. Richard and Rachel, on the other hand, aren’t going to go ahead without your support, and this cold war isn’t good for anybody. (pause) Honey, what if Richard and Rachel were gay?

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Oh, please!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m serious. What would you say if they were a gay male couple who wanted to start a family and Sadie wanted to help them?

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: I’d say... mazel tov, now go get some girl off the internet and leave us out of it. Sadie doesn’t realize what it is she’s doing. She's just... throwing her genetic material around like it’s... popcorn. Auctioning off family property like it’s no big deal.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (almost to himself) They are our family.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Richard and Rachel are our family. The words hang there. Then, Charlie notices something on his wife’s face. He reaches over to remove it and Cynthia rears back.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: What!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You've got something on your chin. Cynthia turns away and grabs at her chin to discover an errant piece of toilet paper.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: It’s nothing. It’s just...  78

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It’s bleeding. She touches her chin with the back of her hand and sees a little red smear.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: It’s just... a thing. A pimple. It’s fine. My god. Charlie watches his high-strung wife grab tissues and pre them against her chin.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I got into Berkeley. The couple turn to see their daughter holding a letter.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: My early decision letter came. I got in. Charlie jumps out of bed and gives Charlotte a congratulatory hug. Cynthia’s eyes well up.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That’s great, honey. We are so proud of you. Isn’t it great, Cyn? Cynthia is caught in a swirl of confused emotions, but she manages a smile.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Yes. It is. It’s great, honey. I’m so happy for you... Charlotte smiles, then notices something.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLOTTE
dialogues.text: What happened to your face, mom?

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Oh. It’s... fine. It’s just... -- but it’s not fine. The damn breaks, and Cynthia bursts into sobs.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...no--thing...  79 INT. RACHEL AND RICHARD’S LOBBY - DAY Rachel opens their mailbox and finds a thick envelope fro “Conceptions.” She pauses for a moment, then tears it ope

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (ON PHONE, PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: Sadie Barrett has applied to become a donor in the Conceptions Oocyte Donor Program.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard’s cellphone is on speaker-mode as he and Sadie li

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: The purpose of this evaluation is to assess her appropriateness as a donor and to gain insight into her psychological and emotional well- being... INT. RACHEL AND RICHARD’S APARTMENT - DAY Rachel paces and reads into her phone. INTERCUT. Psychological testing indicates that all clinical scales are within normal limits.... no significant evidence of psychopathology. Sadie does a fist pump and hoots. Richard gives a thumbs Okay, here’s the good part: Ms. Barrett presented as a bright, sophisticated and charismatic young woman -- Sadie beams and curtsies. -- who appears comfortable with her decision to donate. She is mature and intelligent and it is likely that she will comply with the medical demands of the donation... In conclusion, Ms. Barrett is approved as a candidate for oocyte donation. Richard raises his hand. Sadie gives him a high-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cynthia, stunned, sits across from her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: You passed?  80

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Why are you so surprised?

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: I’m not. I’m just... I thought they might have some reservations about someone with a... mental health history.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: I don’t have a mental health history... dad does.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: It is genetic, you know.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Okay. Fine. I have some depression and anxiety. Maybe a little OCD, but the normal amount that everybody has. A WAITER arrives.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Can I take your order?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: I’1ll have the kale salad with a Zoloft to start and a side of Klonopin. Unfazed, the waiter just stares at Sadie who smiles and h him her menu. Cynthia shakes her head, amused, then hands over her own menu.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: The risotto, please. The waiter leaves.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Oh, and, by the way, I talked to Dad and he’s fine with it.

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: He is?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Totally. He said he thought it was a wonderful thing to do for two people I love. He’s proud of me. Cynthia’s throat tightens.  81

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: Well, he always has been a big believer in spreading genetic material around without putting much thought into the consequences. Sadie looks away and sighs. I’m sorry. I’m sorry. She lays her hand on her daughter’s and looks her in the You know, I love you, right? Sadie nods, but not right away. And even though I don’t agree with you, at all -- I respect you. And if this... project is something you feel that you have to do, then... you should do it.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: So you’re cool with it?

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: No, I’m not cool with... anything. Ever. But I see how much this means to you and I don’t want to stand in your way. I want to... to support you... no matter what.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: You do? Cynthia nods. Mother and daughter smile at each other, tears brimming in their eyes. Then --

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: It doesn’t mean I’m happy about it. INT. RACHEL AND RICHARD’S APARTMENT - KITCHEN - DAY A BIG BOX is sliced open to reveal a CORNUCOPIA OF FERTIL MEDICATION AND SUPPLIES: vials, syringes, needles, a red plastic sharps container... WIDER -- Our trio stands over the box, admiring the conte

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Whoa. Christmas. LATER -- Sadie watches, fascinated, as Richard prepares a pair of identical injections. It’s an exacting process. Rachel, nearby, chomps on an apple.  82 SADIE (CONT’D) (examining a vial) What does this stuff do?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Shuts down our reproductive systems so they can synch up our cycles.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Yikes. Any risk of like, triggering menopause?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Technically, it is menopause. Chemically induced, but it’s temporary so...

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (holding a syringe) Okay, I’m going to do Rachel first. Rachel lifts the bottom of her shirt and unbuttons her je to expose her lower abdomen. Richard wipes the area with alcohol, pinches the skin and aims.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ready?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: One, two, three -- He confidently jabs the needle in. Sadie watches, mouth a

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: See. Subcutaneous. No biggie.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (turning to Sadie) Okay. Your turn. Sadie eagerly starts undoing her belt.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Oh, my god. This is so glamorous. We're like “Drugstore Cowboy.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUPER-8 style glimpses of Richard, Rachel and Sadie as th film each other at 16fps using Sadie’s app on her phone. montage sketches a portrait of our trio’s life together a also serves as a little homage to the East Village. They vamp for the camera. They cook. They bike.  83 They swing on playground swings, play with the dogs in Tompkins Square Park, and work (along with Sam) at Pickle Guy. INT. DORDICK’S OFFICE - WAITING ROOM - DAY An abrupt cut to the HUSH of the waiting room. Rachel rea a magazine. Above her, the WIRE MATERNITY MOBILE TAPS.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: All done. Rachel looks up to find Sadie putting on her coat. EXT. DORDICK’S OFFICE - DAY As they exit, Sadie pulls two lollipops from her pocket a offers one to Rachel, who takes it.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: He wants me to start stimming. Rachel slows to a stop, takes the lollipop from her mouth and looks at Sadie. INT. RACHEL AND RICHARD’S APARTMENT - KITCHEN - DAY The FRONT DOOR bursts open. The dogs rush in, Richard beh them. THE REFRIGERATOR opens. The vegetable drawer slides out. Inside are BOXES OF MEDICATION. One marked FOLLITROP is lifted out, before the drawer is kicked shut. QUICK SHOTS: Richard scrubs his hands, Sadie unzips her pants, Rachel swabs Sadie’s belly, Richard assembles the CARTRIDGE, CLICK, CLICK, CLICK. (see instruction video) Richard holds a syringe, poised to inject Sadie’s belly.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Okay. Warning. This stuff can really make you crazy and all-over- the-place.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Emotionally incontinent. I remember. Don’t worry. I can handle it. Richard looks at Rachel, who gives him a nod.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: One, two, three... He injects her as the CAMERA QUICKLY PUSHES IN toward Sad  84

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Ouch. Shit, it stings.

dialogues.speaker: NOW IN THE BEDROOM,
dialogues.text: and high on hormones, Sadie spins around in a VINTAGE DRE I love it! Rachel sits cross-legged, sorting a pile of clothes. Are you sure you don’t want it? It’s in perfect condition.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: No. It’s better for you. I can’t wear that anymore.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Oh, no... You’re not going to start... draping are you? Rachel gives Sadie a puzzled look. Oh, god. My mom went on this jag and got rid of everything in her closet that’s even remotely form fitting. Sadie pulls off the dress and is completely unself-consci in her bra and thong underwear. Rachel can’t help but adm her young and beautiful body. And now it’s just like... cowl necks and tunics and draw strings and shawls. That whole Eileen Fisher thing. She finds her discarded t-shirt and pulls it on. It’s like she doesn’t even have a body anymore. She’s just drowning inside of all this fabric and erased all sexuality from her being. It’s like she’s been spayed. (examining her arms) Can I use some of your lotion? My skin is so dry. I’m molting.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sure. Whatever’s in there. Sadie leaves. Rachel looks down at herself. She is wearin large loose cashmere sweater-thing with kimono sleeves. S quickly pulls it off and tosses it in the pile on her bed only to discover AN EILEEN FISHER LABEL staring back at h  85

dialogues.speaker: SADIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh, my god. My boobs are so big from those drugs. I look like a porn star. Sadie re-enters, rubbing lotion on her face and neck. Rac quickly buries the Eileen Fisher item. You're going to be such a great mom.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I am?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: (sitting on the bed) Uh-huh. Totally. I wish you were my mom.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: That’s crazy.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: No. It’s not. (lays her head on Rachel’s lap) I think of you like that sometimes. Like you’re my art mom. And Richard is my art dad. And I’m your art daughter. And now it’s going to be so intense because a little part of me mixed with a little part of him will be growing inside of you. (a pause, then--) Do you think Sam’s attractive?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Sam, who works at Pickle Guy?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I never thought about it.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: I think he’s attractive in a kind of fucked-up-character-in-a-Sam- Shepard-play way. Broken, but hot. (pause, then --) Do you think our baby will grow up to be a writer?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Yours and Sam's?  86

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: No. Yours and mine. Sadie’s weird choice of words hangs in the air. A RING TONE breaks the silence, and Rachel locates her phone.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Shit. It’s my editor. She climbs off the bed and answers. Sadie lays among the clothes, daydreaming about having an editor of her own one day.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hi. Liz.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ, (THROUGH THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: Have you seen it?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Seen what?

dialogues.speaker: LIZ, (THROUGH THE PHONE)
dialogues.text: The email I just sent you. RACHEL WALKS INTO HER OFFICE... and goes to the COMPUTER. Without sitting, she CLICKS THE MOUSE and scrolls through her In-Box, then stops.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Got it. Rachel DOUBLE CLICKS and looks at the screen. Her express changes. She is crestfallen.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Are you there? Silence. Then, Rachel walks away from the computer and we finally see WHAT IS ON SCREEN -- IT’S A MOCK-UP OF A BOOK JACKET: a young woman stands in field, holding a wildflower as she gazes out over the horizon. Swirly lavender and pink letters read: Women’s Studies A Novel Rachel Biegler

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel hurries alongside her editor, Liz, who is in a rus  87

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: It’s the book jacket. Not the book. It’s a sales tool.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: It’s pink.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: I knew you were going to say that.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Well, that’s because it is, Liz.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: It’s also green.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: When do I talk to somebody about this?

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: That’s what we’re doing now, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: My contract says I get to consult on the cover. Don’t I get to talk to marketing directly? They slow down and then stop in front of a building.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Yes, of course, you can do that, but as your editor and friend, I don’t advise it. It’s just not worth it. I’ve been through this a hundred times. They’11l pretend to “consult” and maybe they’11l tweak the font to placate you. But they won’t really change it. And then you'll become known as “a difficult author.” Or, more likely -- because you're a woman -- just a fucking bitch. If I thought this cover was going to kill your book, I'd tell you. They’re casting a wider net. They want people to buy it. That’s a good thing. Liz hugs Rachel goodbye and disappears into the building. Rachel stands there, looking lost. INT. RICHARD AND RACHEL’S APARTMENT - DAY The dogs eat their breakfast. Richard drinks the last of coffee and puts dishes in the sink. Rachel yells from off  88

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It totally misrepresents the book. Then it’s like -- oh, I just don’t understand the business side of things -- which I don’t -- As Rachel and Richard rush about, preparing for the day, Sadie sits on her inflatable bed with a cup of tea, watch them go in and out of view. Rachel heads into the bathroom to wash up. -- but I do understand that if a guy wrote it, it wouldn’t be packaged like a fucking cupcake. I am so sick of this shit. It’s the same thing with this whole fertility nightmare. I just feel so betrayed.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: By what?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: The bullshit I was fed in college. Feminist ideology. The lie that I could have a career, then kids. Well, obviously, that hasn’t panned out. (spits toothpaste) I should send them the bills for all our IUIs and IVFs.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You can’t blame second-wave feminism for your ambivalence about having a kid.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (emerging) I’m not ambivalent.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Now you’re not, because you realize the boat is leaving the dock. But before... You kept changing the deadline, remember? “We’1ll start as soon as I finish the play... Right after I get this story published... Once I’m done with the book... “ Rachel joins Richard in the foyer. He’s pulling on his bo

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Are you blaming me?  89

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I’m not blaming you. I’m just saying that we need to take some responsibility for the situation.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: A lot of women have babies at forty- one. I thought I could, too.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Okay, but I don’t think it’s Gloria Steinem’s fault that we can’t get pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Whose fault is it, then? Richard is at a loss. Oh, I guess it’s mine. I was too busy writing my stupid book. She lifts her manuscript and drops it so it lands with a

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I didn’t say that.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: All the doctors ever talk about is my advanced maternal age. My old eggs. And then we’re in the middle of an IVF and -- what a surprise! -- your sperm is like... on a sabbatical.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa. What’s that supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Nothing. Let’s just drop it.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: All I’m saying is we can’t blame Doctor Dordick or Bella Abzug or anybody else for our fuck-up.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You mean my fuck up.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Why do I feel like I’m in a Wendy Wasserstein play?  90

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (pulling on her coat) I don’t know, but it’s our anniversary today and I have to go get a... dildo-cam shoved up my twat by Dr. Dordick, so can we not talk about this anymore and just... repress it. Or suppress it. Or whichever one is appropriate in this instance, so we can just keep this train on track... A tense pause. Then --

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: It’s suppress... Richard and Rachel turn to Sadie. ...when you consciously forget something that’s suppression. Repression is unconscious.

dialogues.speaker: DARKNESS, A MURKY UNDULATING LANDSCAPE
dialogues.text: as if we've been plunged into the unconscious mind itself Wider reveals that we are -- INT. DORDICK’S OFFICE - EXAM ROOM - DAY Rachel, a paper sheet over her lap, is looking at an ultrasound image of her uterus on a MONITOR as Dordick Maneuvers a wand between her legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sadie holds a grocery bag and buys flowers from a deli. INT. RACHEL AND RICHARD’S APARTMENT - NIGHT A SERIES OF SHOTS of Sadie alone in the apartment. She ch vegetables. Whisks dressing. Drags the air bed out of the living room. Opens a drop-leaf table. Hangs a paper lante LATER -- Rachel and Richard enter their dark apartment. W FOLLOW THEM as they travel through the foyer and into -- THE LIVING ROOM, where they discover a beautifully set ta with flowers and candles. Sadie pops up from behind the couch with a homemade sign that says “Happy Anniversary!”

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Surprise! The dogs bark with excitement.  91 A CAST IRON PAN as steaks SIZZLE. Sadie stabs the steaks puts them on a dish. SADIE (CONT’D) (calling out) Did you ever read “Innocence” by Harold Brodkey?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Uh, I don’t think so. No.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Me, either. The CAMERA FOLLOWS Sadie as she carries the steaks into t living room, where Rachel and Richard sit at the table.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wait. Is that the Harvard cunnilingus one? Sadie sets the steaks on the table and begins serving.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. That one.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: It’s all about a guy going down on a girl, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: It’s pretty life-altering. Everyone begins eating. I read it in a Contemporary Short Fiction class. Then, as an assignment, I wrote a kind of tongue-in-cheek response to it called, “Experience.”

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: No pun intended. Sadie gives Richard a puzzled look, so he explains, his m full of steak. ...”tongue-in-cheek response” to a story about cunnilingus... Sadie laughs. Rachel rolls her eyes. What? Someone had to say it.  92

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: (sawing at her steak) I kept writing and re-writing and it grew into this forty-five-page- long thing. Anyway, it’s still a work-in-progress, but I was wondering... if you guys were interested... I’d love to hear your thoughts about it.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Yeah. We'd love to read it. Sure.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: (between bites) Oh, my god. That would be so great. But it has to be top secret because my mom’s been asking to see my writing all semester and, oh, my god, the thought of her reading about me “choking on cock,” even ina fictional piece, is horrifying. But it’s fine for you guys because you know how life is. You get it. Several beats of eating, then --

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t be so sure of that...

dialogues.speaker: LATER, IN THE OFFICE --
dialogues.text: A PRINTER spits out pages. Sadie removes a small pile, ta the bottom against the desk to straighten the pages and begins searching for something. She opens a drawer, rifles around, then closes it. She mo some papers around and by chance uncovers -- What looks like two pages from a play. On closer inspecti Sadie realizes the pages are taped to the desk and pauses read this curious document: US: Hi, I’m Rachel. My husband Richard and I placed the a HER: I hope I’m not disturbing... US: No! We’re happy you called.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Did you find it? Startled, Sadie whips around and looks blankly at Rachel. The stapler. That desk is a mess. Rachel goes to the desk, and begins to search. Sadie feel slightly guilty.  93

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: I saw those pages and I thought you were working on a new play.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (amused) Oh, no. That’s definitely not a new play. That’s our cheat sheet. For when a birth mother calls. But it’s been pretty quiet on that front. Rachel retrieves the stapler and hands it to Sadie.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: So... pregnant girls just call you out of the blue?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: They see our ad online or wherever and look at our pictures and read about us and if they’re interested they call. Rachel pulls the computer keyboard closer and opens a website. We see RACHEL AND RICHARD’S PARENT PROFILE with photo of them amid a cheerful, cheesy template.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Would you give your unborn child to these people? (pause) Oh, I guess you sort of are...

dialogues.speaker: LATER --
dialogues.text: As Sadie stands in the foyer, pulling on her coat and sca she looks into the living room and sees Richard on the co leafing through her story.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Oh, my god. You don’t have to look at that tonight.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Hey. It’s our anniversary. I can at least read about fellatio.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Shut up! Rachel playfully throws a pillow and then pounces on him burst of affection.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Bye, guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: (hesitating, then --) To meet Sam. Richard and Rachel are surprised, but act nonchalant.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Oh. Cool.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Cool.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Welp. Have a good time.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Have fun. (unable to suppress it) But don’t have sex. Sadie and Richard look at Rachel. I mean, you know. Not right now.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: I’m not planning on having sex with Sam.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I know. It’s just. You know, if it comes up. You’re extremely fertile at the moment...

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: We're just going to the movies.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (trying to deflect) What’re you guys seeing?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Something at the Anthology Film Archives. A documentary about some music guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 94 Sam and Sadie eat popcorn and watch PHIL SPECTOR (with in hair) on trial for murder. Sam turns to look at Sadie. Sadie senses his gaze and enjoys the attention, but keeps her e the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sadie and Sam stand on the sidewalk. It’s bitter cold.  95

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: That was fun. Thanks. (a pause, then --) Maybe fun isn’t the right word. Sam laughs.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Yeah. Definitely not a good date movie.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: There should be a warning: “Do not bring a date to this movie. Total vibe kill.” Emphasis on kill. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Oh, well. I guess I blew it, then.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Our date.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: What? No. Wait. This isn’t really... She points her finger back and forth between Sam and hers

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I thought so.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: But I don’t think it counts unless both parties agree. So it’s up to you... Are we on a date? They stare at one another. There are definitely sparks.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Good question. They stare some more. Then, almost imperceptibly, Sam lea in. Sadie hesitates, then swallows. I'm thirsty.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Me, too. Wanna get a drink?  96 Sadie nods. A pause. Then Sadie and Sam simultaneously mo toward each other and KISS. WIDE shows the young romantics kissing beneath the marque that reads “The Agony and the Ecstasy of Phil Spector.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thunder and RAIN as Sadie rushes down the street, wearing same clothes as the night before. INT. DORDICK’S OFFICE - WAITING ROOM - DAY Sadie enters, wet and breathless, and finds Rachel and Richard sitting in the packed waiting room. As Sadie unbuttons her coat, Rachel looks at her flatly -- she’s n happy.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Do not freak out. We didn’t do anything. I swear. Just cuddled and kissed. Nothing vaginal. At the word “vaginal,” Richard springs up.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I’m gonna wait in the car. (to Sadie) Take my seat. I’11 see you guys after. He weirdly salutes all the ladies in the room and leaves. sits, and Rachel resumes reading a magazine. Sadie sighs reaches for a magazine of her own.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: The trains were such a mess.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (eyes on her magazine) You missed the appointment.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Didn't you get my text?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Texting isn’t being here on time.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Okay. I’m sorry. But I just told you, the trains were messed up.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You know we’re really grateful for what you’re doing, but this isn’t... content for some Tweet or some thing to post on Facebook.  97

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: I know. I would never do that. What’re you talking about. I don’t even have Twitter. Rachel gets up and walks away. Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: To tell them that you’re here. While Rachel speaks with the receptionist, Sadie glances around nervously. Rachel returns and resumes reading.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: What’d they say?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: They might be able to squeeze you in in a half hour.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Oh. Okay. Cool. So there’s not a problem, then. Sadie picks out a different magazine and flips through it

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I’m going to wait in the car, too. Rachel slaps her magazine shut, stands up and goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel and Richard sit in the car, listening to a podcast Richard dozes reclined in the driver’s seat. Rachel spots Sadie emerging from Dordick’s office, she nudges Richard.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Honey. Richard comes to and sees Sadie. Sadie seems disoriented, so Rachel steps out and waves to her. Over here! As Sadie approaches, Rachel holds TWO LARGE GREEN BEVERAG Look what I got! Sadie smiles and is heading for the rear door when Rachel beats her to it.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: I can sit in the back.  98

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: No. It’s fine. You sit up front. They climb in, and Rachel hands Sadie one of the drinks. It’s a Green Goddess with a shot of wheat grass. Richard takes a closer look at Sadie and notices she look blotchy and weepy.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Are you okay? Sadie nods yes and sucks on her straw for a long moment. Then, unable to contain her emotions, she begins to cry.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, no.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh, god, honey. I’m sorry I got so mad... I think I overreacted. Sadie shakes her head. That’s not it? She shakes her head again. Finally she manages to speak through her tears --

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: The doctor yelled at me and said my eggs weren't developing on schedule.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Dordick yelled at you?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Dr. Russell.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Who’s Dr. Russel?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: I think that was his name. He said I didn’t have enough follicles. That I was a “low responder.” That someone my age should have way more. And they’re not growing at the right rate or something. He said he’s had forty-one-year-olds produce more eggs than me.  99 Sadie begins to sob. Rachel and Richard watch helplessly until -- CLICK! Richard opens the car door and climbs out

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Honey, what are you doing? INT. DORDICK’S OFFICE - DAY Richard approaches the reception desk, soaking wet.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I need to talk to Dr. Russell.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Mr. Grimes. He’s with patients all morning. But I can get a message to him if you'd like.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Yeah. Okay. Tell him that my niece is not a fucking farm animal! The receptionist looks warily at Richard. So do the other women working behind the desk. Write it down. Please. Our donor... Richard grabs a pile of EGG DONATION brochures and flaps around angrily. .---who is giving us the gift of life is being treated like a piece of shit!

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Please keep your voice down, Mr. Grimes. DR. RUSSELL emerges from a room behind the desk.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Is there a problem?

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Dr. Russell, this is Richard Grimes --

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Oh, hey. Doctor Perdue. How are you? Richard places his COAT on the reception desk and reaches over to shake the doctor’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR RUSSEL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry --  100

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Are you? Sorry? Really? Because my niece is out there, crying in my car, feeling like some kind of failed factory farm animal because you told her she wasn’t producing enough goddamn eggs!

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR RUSSELL
dialogues.text: Should I call security?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Should you? I don’t know. You tell me! Richard, preparing to make a dramatic exit, grabs his coa from the desk and accidentally pulls down the plexiglass display rack, sending the brochures flying. The staff and waiting patients stare.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) I’m sorry. I’m sorry. Okay. (kneeling) I‘1l clean this up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our couple watch their dogs race around in the dog run. INT. RICHARD AND RACHEL’S APT - NIGHT Richard and Rachel enter with the dogs. As they pass the living room, they see Sadie on the air bed, writing in he journal. The muffled PARTY sounds filter down from the apartment upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Are those guys keeping you up?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: (shaking her head) I've been living in a dorm. Rachel and Richard smile at her joke.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You know you can call it quits any time you want... Sadie nods. And don’t worry about the stupid numbers, okay? All it takes is one good egg. That’s what they’re always telling us anyway.  101

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam stands at the SLOP SINK filling an electric teapot. Sadie enters, holding her purse.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Hey. How’s it going?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Good. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Good. Sadie points awkwardly toward the unisex stalls.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: I need to -- Sam steps out of the way. Sadie enters a stall and shuts door. Sam stands there for a moment, nervously holding th full tea kettle.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Sadie?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Huh.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Are you freaking out?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Uh. No. Not really. Should I be?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I was just wondering. Because that happens with people sometimes. They get... intimate with someone and then, you know, they spaz.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m not spazzing. Are you?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Cool.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Cool. What about Richard? Was he freaked out?  102

dialogues.speaker: SADIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Nope. He was cool with it. I wouldn’t worry about it, Sam.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I’m not... worried. I’m just, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (amused) Well, there’s nothing to be concerned about. is pretty evolved.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Everyone involved You just seem kind of distant.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m in the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I mean the other morning. before I woke up.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. Sorry. I was something. coy or anything... As Sam listens, he realizes he can A SLIVER OF SADIE through the edge places a syringe between her teeth alcohol swab.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: (slurring) It’s just, there’s a lot shit I’m dealing with at (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam's eyes widen and his jaw drops injects herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like Rachel side, surrounded drug information sheet.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: “Human Jesus. Rachel swabs Sadie’s haunch. did when we first met her, by sheets and pillows. You left late for I’m not trying to be see -- of the stall door. She and wipes her belly with an of personal the moment. open as she expertly RACHEL’S APT - BEDROOM - NIGHT Sadie lies on her She reads from a Chorionic Gonadotropin.” Could it sound more sci-fi.  103

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: They call it the trigger shot. It makes you ovulate. Then 36 hours later, the retrieval and... finito. Richard appears with a large intramuscular needle.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Okay. You ready?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Alrightie. He places one hand on Sadie, takes aim -- One... two... three. -- and spears the needle into her. He pulls the plunger b to check for blood. Then he pushes the plunger down. Almost done. Almost done. Almost done. Done. Richard pulls the needle out. Rachel presses a swab again the injection site and hands Sadie a bag of frozen peas.

dialogues.speaker: LATER --
dialogues.text: All three of them are lying in the bed, staring at the ceiling. After a few seconds of silence --

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I guess it’s stating the obvious, but we couldn’t have done this without you. Sadie smiles.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Oh, my god. You know what we never even talked about?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: The whole birthing thing. Are you guys going to do it like at home with a doula without drugs? Natural childbirth. Richard and Rachel contemplate the question. Then --  104

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Nothing about this has been natural so far, so I don’t see why we would all of a sudden wanna start... FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: ANESTHESIOLOGIST, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: You're going to feel a prick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sadie, with drooping eyelids, lies on the table as the ANESTHESIOLOGIST injects her with a sedative. It’s the sa guy who administered Rachel’s anesthesia, and he gives Sa the exact same spiel about his daughter visiting his job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel and Richard stand beside Sadie’s bed as she wakes

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Did they get a lot?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Twenty-four eggs. Sadie tries to absorb this tally. Rachel smiles warmly. You did great. Sadie seems relieved. They all blink back tears. INT. RACHEL AND RICHARD’S APARTMENT - DAY IN THE OFFICE -- Rachel presses a phone against her ear a she scribbles on a pad.

dialogues.speaker: LATER, IN THE BEDROOM --
dialogues.text: Sadie is camped out in Rachel and Richard’s bed. She’s pa and buried under the blankets. Rachel excitedly reads fro her notes.  105

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: They did ICSI on fifteen. Six fertilized. And they’re watching two more.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: (weak and wan) Is that good? (off Rachel’s nod) I’m so happy.

dialogues.speaker: THE NEXT MORNING --
dialogues.text: Rachel and Richard drink the last of their coffee and pla dishes in the sink.

dialogues.speaker: MEANWHILE, IN THE BATHROOM --
dialogues.text: Sadie stands on a scale in her sleeping shirt and calls i the other room --

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Did you gain a lot of weight after? I swear I’ve put on like twelve pounds in three days.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE FOYER
dialogues.text: Richard and Rachel are pulling on their coats.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Sometimes it takes a while for your body to re-adjust after all the hormones. I wouldn’t worry about it. Coffee’s on the table. And scrambled eggs and strawberries.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Feel better.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (as they leave) See you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiting for the elevator.  106

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: How is she gaining weight? She hasn't eaten anything in two days.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: It’s water retention. It’s totally normal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard rolls his bike in, leans it against a wall. Sam i already there, working on a computer.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Sadie’s not coming in?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Nah. She’s not feeling too good.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: That’s too bad. Richard sifts through mail as Sam works up his courage. I need to tell you something, Rich. I was thinking I should talk to Sadie about it first, but then I thought I should just tell you as soon as possible.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (apprehensive) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I think Sadie’s in trouble. Yesterday in the bathroom. She was in the stall. And I was at the sink. And we were talking, you know, through the door. But then I realized I could see her through an opening. Richard just stares at Sam, waiting for him to make his p She was shooting up.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: It’s crazy. I never would have suspected it. She shoots it in her gut. To hide the marks, I guess. Richard starts laughing. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 107 What the fuck, Rich? It’s not funny.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I’m sorry. It’s not what you think. She’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: What do you mean? Fine? She’s got a fucking monkey on her back, man. This makes Richard laugh more. Sam stares at him, horrifi INT. RACHEL AND RICHARD’S APARTMENT - ALL - NIGHT Rachel enters with a groceries and mail. She puts the bag down, pulls off her coat and glances into the kitchen to discover that the coffee and breakfast she made Sadie are exactly where she left them. Rachel makes her way down the hall and looks into the bed where Sadie sleeps with the TV on. Rachel observes Sadie a moment, then shuts off the TV.

dialogues.speaker: LATER--
dialogues.text: Richard and Rachel sleep on the inflatable mattress. The sound of WHIMPERING wakes Richard. When he goes to investigate, he finds Sadie in the bathroom, sitting on t side of the tub, holding her stomach and crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sadie, frail and unwell, sits in the backseat between Ric and Rachel. Richard stares straight ahead, very upset, wh Rachel nervously watches Sadie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sadie talks to an E.R. Doctor who palpates her abdomen.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Oww.

dialogues.speaker: E.R. DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Sorry. Okay. What about here?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Oww.

dialogues.speaker: E.R. DOCTOR
dialogues.text: When did the pain begin?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: It started a few days ago after the retrieval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in the middle of an IVF.

dialogues.speaker: E.R. DOCTOR
dialogues.text: You're trying to get pregnant?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I am. The CAMERA PANS to find Rachel slouched in a chair, raised. The doctor is thoroughly confused.

dialogues.speaker: ER DOCTOR
dialogues.text: (re: Richard and Rachel) I thought you two were her parents.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Prospective parents.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: She’s my aunt. He’s my uncle. I’m just the donor. The doctor tries to make sense of this arrangement.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: It’s complicated.

dialogues.speaker: ER DOCTOR
dialogues.text: I can see that. (back to business) Were there any difficulties with the retrieval?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Actually... yeah... Well, sort of. 108 hand This comes as a surprise to Richard and Rachel, who are a to interrupt when the doctor raises a hand to stop them.

dialogues.speaker: E.R. DOCTOR
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: Um, well... I wasn’t... I mean, I didn’t have enough follicles. (hesitating, then --) So I upped the dose of the Follitropin.  109

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: By how much? Sadie holds her thumb and forefinger a quarter inch apart

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Oh, god. That doctor is an idiot.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: It wasn’t him. He didn’t tell me to do it. (off their confusion) I did it myself.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: I increased the dosage on my own. Rachel and Richard stare at Sadie in disbelief. I really wanted this to work out for you guys. You’ve spent so much money. And I know how much it means to you and... (starting to cry) I didn’t want to disappoint you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard is on the phone, pacing, with Rachel standing nea

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome. They did an ultrasound and said her left ovary was enlarged... They want to keep her overnight. Richard listens, then reluctantly answers a question -- About the size of a grapefruit. Richard shuts his eyes and listens then hangs up and turn to Rachel. They're on their way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cynthia and Charlie exit an elevator and stop at a nurses station to ask for directions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cynthia and Charlie warily enter the room --  110

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Knock. Knock. Richard and Rachel both stand. As soon as Cynthia sees Sadie, her face crumples.

dialogues.speaker: SADIE
dialogues.text: It’s okay, mom. I’m fine. They’re just observing. Rachel offers Cynthia the chair next to Sadie’s bed, and two women wordlessly brush past each other. It wasn’t their fault. It was me. I was the idiot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel, Richard, Charlie and Cynthia sit at a table, lit the glow of the snack machines that line the wall. There a terrible drawn-out silence. Finally, Cynthia stands --

dialogues.speaker: CYNTHIA
dialogues.text: I’m gonna go back to the room. INT. RICHARD AND RACHEL’S - FOYER - NIGHT Richard and Rachel enter their apartment. The dogs greet

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard walks the dogs, looks up at his apartment, catche glimpse of Rachel’s figure in the window and stares at he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LATER, IN THE BATHROOM -- Rachel tears open a foil packag ESTROGEN PATCHES and applies one to her stomach.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (CALLING)
dialogues.text: Don’t forget we need to do my progesterone.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Richard is squeezing the air out of the inflatable bed. He’s heard Rachel but doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Richard?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Yeah. Okay.  111

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Rachel lies on her side, arranging herself on the bed. Richard shambles in with a syringe and a bag of frozen pe

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Dordick said my lining looks beautiful. He said most women would kill for a lining like mine. Isn’t that great? Richard kneels behind Rachel preparing to give her the in

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (dully) Yeah. It’s great.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Are you even listening?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Yeah. I am. But I’ma little preoccupied. Didn’t we do this side last night? She swivels around so her head is at the foot of the bed her feet are at the top.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Anyway, I’m trying to talk to you about something important.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: My endometrium.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (swabbing her) What about it?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
